except when necessarily open during the use thereof, and during such time the same shall be properly
guarded and protected. (1991 Code § 19-10)
8-1-8: CONGREGATING ON SIDEWALK:
It shall be unlawful for any person or assemblage of persons to obstruct any sidewalk or passage or
any street or alley or any public walk in the City by congregating or in any way assembling therein or
thereon. (1991 Code § 19-12)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 182/382
8-1-9: REFUSE ON SIDEWALK:
A. Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any property owner, occupant or agent of any property that abuts
or adjoins any street or avenue in the City to allow or permit any animal or vegetable substance, or
any tin, glass, or pieces of iron, or any trash, mud, snow, ice, dirt, slop, refuse matter, or filth of any
kind or description whatever, to accumulate or remain on any part of the sidewalk abutting or
adjacent to the premises owned or occupied by such person. (1991 Code § 19-13)
B. Failure To Remove Or Clean After Notice: If any such property owner, occupant or agent of such
property shall fail or refuse to clean off the sidewalk abutting or adjacent to the property owned or
occupied by him within twenty four (24) hours after notice served on him by any police officer,
Code Enforcement Officer, Street Superintendent or any other agent of the City, such property
owner or occupant or agent shall be guilty of an offense. (1991 Code § 19-13; amd. 2007 Code)
8-1-10: DISTRIBUTING CIRCULARS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, leave or deposit, or cause to be thrown, left or deposited
upon any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk or public square, public enclosure or lot, vacant or occupied,
any paper, circular, newspaper, letter, handbill, poster or anything that is liable to be blown about by
the wind. (1991 Code § 19-14)
8-1-11: PENALTY:
Unless stated otherwise, violations of this chapter, including articles A and B of this chapter, are
punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1991 Code § 19-1)
ARTICLE A. SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR
8-1A-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
A. Compliance With Provisions: All sidewalk construction and repair on any street, avenue or alley in
the city shall be done subject to and shall strictly conform in all respects to all provisions set forth in
this article.
B. Permit Required: No person shall build, construct or repair any sidewalk on any street, avenue or
alley in the city without first having obtained a written permit from the city clerk.
C. Contents Of Permit: The permit shall show the name of the property owner, the contractor or
person who is to do the work, and the lot and block numbers on which the work is to be done, and
the addition or part of the city in which it is located. (1991 Code § 19-41)
8-1A-2: PERMIT CONDITIONS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 183/382
All permits issued for sidewalk construction or repair shall be issued on the condition that the work will
be done strictly in accord with this code and city ordinances relating to the same, and all persons
having any part or interest in any sidewalk construction or repair are charged with and bound by the
provisions of this article, notwithstanding the same may not be specially set forth in the permit. (1991
Code § 19-42)
8-1A-3: INSPECTION; CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL:
All sidewalk construction and repair work shall be under the direct supervision of the city's engineer,
public works director, or street superintendent. It shall be his duty when any construction or repair
work has been completely finished in accordance with the ordinances relating to the same to issue a
certificate of approval, a copy of which shall be filed with the city clerk. A copy of the certificate shall
be given to the contractor and a copy to the owner of the property. No right of action for work done or
labor or materials supplied on any contract for sidewalk construction or repair shall arise nor shall any
materialman's or laborer's lien be held to be established until the inspector has approved the work and
issued and delivered his certificate of approval to the person claiming such rights or lien. The
certificate herein mentioned shall be issued only after the completion of the work and shall certify that
the work and materials in all respects comply with this code and city ordinances. (1991 Code § 19-43;
amd. 2007 Code)
8-1A-4: SPECIFICATIONS:
All sidewalks construction in the city shall conform to all specifications promulgated or approved by the
city. (1991 Code § 19-44)
8-1A-5: MAINTENANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit the sidewalk adjacent to his premises to be or continue in
a broken or unsafe condition so as to endanger life and limb of any person traveling thereon. (1991
Code § 19-45)
8-1A-6: REPAIRS:
All sidewalks out of repair shall be repaired with good material of the same kind and dimensions, and
of a quality equal to that originally used in the construction of the sidewalk, and well laid so as to
correspond with the rest of the sidewalk. Such portion of the sidewalk as has settled so as to make
depressions, or become raised above the grade of the sidewalk shall be replaced on the same grade
as the rest of the sidewalk. (1991 Code § 19-46)
8-1A-7: CONDEMNATION:
The city council may at any time, by resolution, condemn any portion of sidewalk whenever in its
judgment it shall be deemed necessary, and provide for the construction of a new sidewalk in
accordance with this article and other ordinances of the city. (1991 Code § 19-47)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 184/382
ARTICLE B. LIMITED ACCESS FACILITIES
8-1B-1: SYSTEM ESTABLISHED:
A system of limited access facilities, consisting of the streets, avenues, boulevards and ways and
parts of streets, avenues, boulevards and ways hereinafter described, is hereby established and
created within the city. In recognition of the general use of such streets, avenues, boulevards, ways
and parts thereof, and of the wear and destruction of the same by heavy general traffic thereon,
including passenger automobiles, buses, trucks, and other vehicles, and to the extent that the costs of
acquisition of rights of way and property necessary in the establishment of such limited access
facilities exceed the benefits to property abutting thereon, such limited access facilities are hereby
declared to be improvements of a general nature, and such costs, to the extent that they exceed the
benefits to property abutting thereon, are hereby declared to be costs of a general nature. (1991 Code
§ 19-71)
8-1B-2: DESIGNATION OF FACILITIES:
The following streets, avenues, boulevards, and ways, and parts of streets, avenues, boulevards and
ways within the city are hereby designated as limited access, arterial and auxiliary service highways,
the same being streets or highways especially designed for through traffic, entrance into which at
intersections may be limited by requiring all entering vehicles to be brought to a complete stop, and
the city council may otherwise protect the right of way of vehicles thereon. Such limited access,
arterial and auxiliary service highways are described as follows: (1991 Code § 19-72)
A. Limited Access Highways:
Gary Boulevard, from the south city limits near the southwest corner, northeasterly along the
A.T.&S.F. track to the intersection, thence east to the east city limits.
South Fourth Street, from Gary Boulevard south to the south city limits.
North Sixth Street, from Gary Boulevard north to the north city limits. (1991 Code § 19-72; amd.
2007 Code)
B. Arterial Highways:
Modell Avenue, from the west city limits, east to Fourth Street.
Thirteenth Street, from the north city limits, south to the south city limits.
C. Auxiliary Service Highways:
Avant Avenue, from South Fourth Street to Gary Boulevard.
Custer Avenue, from the intersection at Fifteenth Street west to the west city limits.
Frisco Avenue, from Glenn Smith Road to Gary Boulevard.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 185/382
Glenn Smith Road, from Gary Boulevard south to Southeast Road.
Hayes Avenue, from Glenn Smith Road to Gary Boulevard.
Neptune Drive and Neptune Avenue, from South Tenth Street south and west to city limits.
Nowahy Avenue, from First Street west to the west city limits.
Southeast Road, from Glenn Smith Road east to waste disposal plant.
Third Street, from Avant to Gary Boulevard.
Fourth Street, from Gary Boulevard north to the end of street.
Fifth Street, from Avant to Gary Boulevard.
Sixth Street, from Gary Boulevard south to Neptune Drive (Opal Avenue).
Seventh Street, from Avant to Gary Boulevard.
Eighth Street, from Avant to Gary Boulevard.
Ninth Street, from Avant north to Nowahy.
Tenth Street, from Gary Boulevard south to Neptune Drive. (1991 Code § 19-72)
8-1B-3: REGULATION AND USE:
The use of limited access facilities within the city shall be regulated and controlled by the traffic
ordinances of the city. (1991 Code § 19-73)
8-1B-4: ZONING NOT AFFECTED:
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to affect any provision of title 11 of this code relating to
the construction or use of improvements on property abutting on any limited access facility. (1991
Code § 19-74)
Chapter 2
TREES
8-2-1: TRIMMING REQUIRED; NOTICE; NONCOMPLIANCE:
A. Property Owner Responsibility: It is the duty of every person who is the owner of, or who as agent
has the control of, any real property or premises situated within the limits of the city, abutting on
any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place, upon being notified so to do, to trim and keep
trimmed all trees on such real property and premises and the parking contiguous and adjacent
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 186/382
thereto, the branches of which overhang any portion of such streets, alleys, sidewalks or other
public places in such manner that the lowermost branches thereof shall be at least thirteen feet six
inches (13'6") above the level of the portion of such streets, alleys, sidewalks or other places so
overhung by such branches. (1991 Code § 22-1; amd. 2007 Code)
B. Failure To Comply: If the owner or agent having control of any real property or premises coming
under this chapter, after having been notified so to do and after the lapse of a reasonable time
thereafter, not to exceed ten (10) days, shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the requirements
of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the code enforcement officer to cause the work to be done at
the expense of the owner of such real property and premises, and any expense incurred in the
doing of the same shall be assessed against such real property and premises and certified to the
county treasurer for collection as are other taxes. (1991 Code § 22-2; amd. 2007 Code)
8-2-2: TRIMMING FOR STRINGING WIRES; PERMIT:
A. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to trim, cut, or otherwise mutilate any shade or
ornamental tree on any street, parking or other public place in the city for the purpose of stringing
wires or cables along or across the parkings or other public places, without first obtaining a permit
therefor from the code enforcement officer. (1991 Code § 22-3; amd. 2007 Code)
B. Application For Permit; Supervision Of Work: Any person desiring a permit required by subsection
A of this section shall make application to the code enforcement officer. If the code enforcement
officer shall be of the opinion that it is necessary for the proper stringing of such wires to trim or cut
any trees, and the same can be done without serious injury to the trees, he shall grant a permit
therefor; provided, however, that no such trimming or cutting of trees shall be done except under
the supervision and control of the code enforcement officer or some competent person designated
by the code enforcement officer. (1991 Code § 22-4; amd. 2007 Code)
8-2-3: PLANTING TREES:
A. City Approval Required: No trees shall be planted on any street parking, alley or public place within
the city until an application has been filed with the city clerk and has been considered and
approved by the city council.
B. Compliance With City Requirements: The application shall show the number and kind of trees to be
planted, their location, space between, the distance from curb and sidewalk lines respectively, and
that all trees are free from all plant diseases. The planting of trees shall conform to all provisions of
this code, resolutions or ordinances as may be in force at the time of planting. (1991 Code § 22-5)
8-2-4: DAMAGING TREES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, scar, break or bend any limbs or otherwise injure any shade
tree on the streets, alleys or public places of the city, except in compliance with this chapter. (1991
Code § 22-6)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 187/382
8-2-5: PROTECTION FROM INSECTS, DISEASE:
A. Insects And Worms: Each owner or occupant of property that abuts a public right of way shall use
every reasonable precaution to protect any shade tree on the property from insects and worms.
(1991 Code § 22-7)
B. Bag Worms:
1. Each owner or occupant of property that abuts a public right of way shall protect any shade
trees on the property from thyridopteryx ephemeraeformis, commonly known as the "bag worm".
(1991 Code § 22-8)
2. When any tree coming under subsection B1 of this section has thyridopteryx ephemeraeformis,
or "bag worms", on them or any "bags" or anything from which bag worms originate or grow, it
shall be the duty of the city manager or his designee to give the owner, agent, or occupant of the
property in front of or upon which such trees are planted a notice in writing to destroy the worms
or bags or anything from which the worms originate or grow within five (5) days from the service
of the notice. When the notice is not complied with, such condition existing contrary to this
section shall be a nuisance and may be abated according to the procedures outlined in title 5,
chapter 1 of this code. (1991 Code § 22-9)
Chapter 3
LIBRARY
8-3-1: PUBLIC LIBRARY ADVISORY BOARD:
A. Board Created; Membership: The Clinton public library advisory board to the city council is hereby
created. The library board shall consist of six (6) members appointed by the city manager.
B. Term: The term of office of each appointive member shall be for three (3) years, beginning July 1 of
the year of appointment, or until his successor has been appointed and qualified. (1991 Code § 18-
32)
C. Execution Of Agreement: The Clinton public library advisory board, after prior approval by the city
council, is hereby authorized to execute an agreement with the multicounty library system as to
policies, operational procedures, supervision and direction of the librarian and employees
operating in the Clinton public library, which agreement shall be made before incorporation of the
library becomes effective. (1991 Code § 18-35)
8-3-2: PARTICIPATION IN MULTICOUNTY LIBRARY SYSTEM:
It is the desire of the city council to provide good library service to the residents of the city through
participation in a multicounty library system. (1991 Code § 18-26)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 188/382
8-3-3: COUNTIES SERVED:
A multicounty library system, legally organized and operated according to state law in accordance with
the Oklahoma library code1, serves the following counties: Custer, Dewey and Washita; provided,
however, that additional counties may be added to the district if approved by the state department of
libraries board. This system is the Western Plains library system. (1991 Code § 18-27)
8-3-4: FINANCIAL SUPPORT:
The multicounty library system is supported by a special recurring ad valorem tax levy approved by
vote of the people for this purpose in accordance with the Oklahoma library code and the constitution
of the state. (1991 Code § 18-28)
8-3-5: CITY IN DISTRICT; STATUS:
A. Within District: The city is located within the district served by the multicounty library system legally
established and operating. (1991 Code § 18-29)
B. Status Of City: The city is the owner and possessor of the Clinton public library and operates the
library for the benefit of the people of the city, and under the provisions of the Oklahoma library
code, the city is a legal and active participant in the multicounty library system. (1991 Code § 18-
30)
8-3-6: LIBRARY INCORPORATED INTO SYSTEM:
The Clinton public library is hereby incorporated into the multicounty library system in accordance with
the provisions of the Oklahoma library code, and the city will provide maintenance, janitor and
necessary utility services for the library quarters. The multicounty library will assume operation and
direction of such library and bear all other expenses, except that the city may from time to time at its
option appropriate funds for operation and/or improvements of the Clinton public library. (1991 Code
§ 18-31)
8-3-7: TITLE TO PROPERTY NOT TRANSFERRED:
The incorporation of the library into the multicounty system shall not constitute a transfer of title to the
real estate, building, equipment, furniture, books and periodicals, or any other property owned by the
city in the Clinton public library. (1991 Code § 18-33)
8-3-8: GIFTS TO LIBRARY:
Any gifts made to Clinton public library, including memorials for books, shall not be owned by or be
subject to the direction of the multicounty library system, and the administration of such funds,
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 189/382
including the disbursement thereof, shall be under the supervision of the Clinton public library advisory
board. (1991 Code § 18-34)
Chapter 4
CEMETERY
8-4-1: CLINTON CEMETERY; DESCRIPTION:
A. Description: Clinton Cemetery is hereby declared the public cemetery of the city, and shall be
described as follows:
A part of the NW/4 of Section 34, Township 12 North, Range 17W, I.M., Custer County, Oklahoma,
particularly described as follows: Beginning at the Northwest corner of said Section 34, thence
East 660 feet along the North boundary line of said Section 34; thence South 1,980 feet; thence
west 660 feet to the West boundary line of said Section 34; thence North 1,980 feet along said
West boundary line of said Section 34 to the point of beginning, including Cedar Hill cemetery and
Clinton cemetery, containing 30 acres, is declared to be the public cemetery of the City of Clinton,
to be known as Clinton cemetery.
B. Official Map: An official map of the Clinton Cemetery shall at all times be on file at the office of the
city clerk.
C. Use: The cemetery is set apart only for the burial, entombment or inurnment of human remains and
shall only be used as such in perpetuity. (1991 Code § 5.5-1)
8-4-2: CEMETERY NOT PERPETUAL CARE CEMETERY:
A. City Not Responsible: Clinton Cemetery is not one of perpetual care and the city shall be under no
obligation to maintain any set standard for its care and upkeep.
B. General Maintenance And Care: The city shall endeavor to provide general maintenance and care
to the cemetery in keeping with the reminder that it is sacredly devoted to the interment,
entombment or inurnment of the dead. (1991 Code § 5.5-2)
8-4-3: BURIALS RESTRICTED TO CEMETERY:
No human body shall be buried within the city limits, except in Clinton Cemetery. (1991 Code § 5.5-3)
8-4-4: DUTIES OF CITY CLERK AND CEMETERY SUPERVISOR:
The city clerk shall be responsible for the administration of the cemetery and for the enforcement of all
ordinances, rules, regulations, policies and procedures approved by the city council pertaining thereto.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 190/382
The cemetery supervisor, as designated by the city manager, shall supervise all workers within the
boundaries of the cemetery. The supervisor shall have the authority to cause the expulsion from the
cemetery of a person who violates this chapter or whose conduct is considered to be contrary to the
accepted decorum of the cemetery. (1991 Code § 5.5-4; amd. Ord. 757A, 5-19-2015)
8-4-5: LIABILITY DISCLAIMER:
The city shall not be held liable for errors or damages which may occur as a result of telephone
instructions from space owners and their legal representatives, or funeral directors, acting on behalf of
the owner or his or her heirs. The city shall take reasonable precaution(s) to protect space owners and
the burial rights of owners within the cemetery. It disclaims all responsibility for loss or damage caused
by flooding, fire, windstorm or other causes deemed an act of God, a common enemy, thieves,
vandals, strikes, malicious mischief makers, explosions, unavoidable accidents, invasions,
insurrections, riots or order of any military or civil authority, whether the damage be direct or collateral.
The city has the right without prior approval of the space owner or his or her legal representative to
correct errors made in good faith, in any phase of cemetery administration, operation or maintenance
without incurring liability of any kind whatsoever. (1991 Code § 5.5-5)
8-4-6: CONDUCT OF CITY EMPLOYEES:
City employees shall be prohibited from working for individual property owners in the cemetery at any
time while on the payroll of the city or from receiving tips or gratuities. This does not prohibit
employees from working on their own time for individual owners of lots in the cemetery. (1991 Code
§ 5.5-6)
8-4-7: HOURS OF OPERATION:
A. Hours For Interments Designated: The cemetery shall be open for interments from eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M. to five o'clock (5:00) P.M., daily with the exception of all Sundays, New Year's Day,
Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, Veterans Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas, and any other
days so designated by the city council.
B. Special Burial Circumstances: Where immediate burial is required by the laws of the state of
Oklahoma or under the rules and regulations of the board of health, interments may be made on
Sundays and holidays, but an additional fee will be added to the regular interment charge, and
entrance into the cemetery will be allowed only to the hearse and vehicles in the funeral
procession.
C. Prohibited Hours: It shall be unlawful for any person to be in the cemetery between the hours of ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (1991 Code § 5.5-7)
8-4-8: CITY RIGHTS CONCERNING WORK WITHIN CEMETERY:
The city has and reserves the following rights and duties:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 191/382
A. The perpetual right of ingress and egress over all spaces.
B. The right to change, modify or replat any part of the cemetery not sold for burial purposes.
C. The right, but not the duty, to increase the size of any burial space already sold for burial purposes
to conform with current lot size requirements so long as no charge to the owner is made for such
increased size.
D. The right to abandon portions of walkway areas in the cemetery as needed to increase the size of
any burial lot to conform to space size requirements. (1991 Code § 5.5-8)
8-4-9: SALES OF SPACES BY CITY OR LOT OWNER; DEEDS:
A. Sales; Issuance Of Deeds:
1. The city clerk, or designated cemetery staff, shall have the duty to show available spaces to
prospective purchasers and to conclude the sale of such spaces. An agreement of sale shall be
completed at the time of purchase. A deed to the property will be issued by the city only upon
receipt of full payment. Such deed shall be subject to the applicable ordinances of the city, laws
of the state, and such restrictions as are of record. The sales agreement, deed, ordinances and
any amendments thereto, shall constitute the sole agreement between the city and the
purchaser and no other agreement shall be recognized by the city. Spaces may be purchased
on an installment basis in accordance with the terms of the agreement of sale; provided,
however, that interment in or the placing of a memorial on a space shall not be permitted until
the purchase price of that space has been paid in full. Deeds to spaces in Clinton cemetery shall
be executed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk with the common seal of the city affixed.
Descriptions of lots will be in accordance with the cemetery plats which are kept on file in the city
clerk's office.
2. All funds from sale of spaces and opening and closing of graves shall be divided as follows:
a. Eighty seven and one-half percent (87.5%) to the general fund.
b. Twelve and one-half percent (12.5%) to the cemetery care fund to be used for purchase of
additional land for cemetery use and capital improvements to the cemetery. (1991 Code § 5.5-
9; amd. 2007 Code)
B. Purchase Of Single Grave Spaces: Single grave spaces may be purchased only in those sections
of the cemetery designated for that purpose. Single grave spaces shall be paid for in full at the
time of use. Grave spaces will be sold in regular order as shown on the plans on file in the city
clerk's office. (1991 Code § 5.5-10)
C. Sale Of Lots Purchased; Recording Fee: A space owner may sell or transfer his or her space,
provided such transaction is recorded in the office of the city clerk. A recording fee as set by the
city council shall be charged for the recording. (1991 Code § 5.5-12)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 192/382
8-4-10: NOTICES TO SPACE OWNERS:
It shall be the duty of each space owner to keep the city informed as to his or her correct mailing
address and the correct address of his or her legal representative, if notices are to be sent to that
representative. Notices or other correspondence mailed to the address on file with the city of the
space owner shall constitute actual delivery and notification. (1991 Code § 5.5-11)
8-4-11: RIGHT OF INTERMENT IN SPACES; DECLARATION:
A. Designation; Order Of Interment: The owner of a space may present his or her deed to the city
clerk designating in writing persons entitled to be buried in the space or spaces owned. This
designation may be amended at any time by the owner in the same manner as the original
designation. In the event the owner fails to designate burial rights for the space or spaces owned,
and in the event the property is not transferred or conveyed as provided herein, the right of
interment in the space or spaces shall be in the following order:
1. One space, niche or crypt shall be forever reserved for the owner and one for the owner's
surviving spouse, if any.
2. The remaining spaces shall pass to the heirs or devises of the owner in the same manner as
real property passes under Oklahoma law; provided, however, that no person shall be interred in
a space passing under this section unless such person would have been eligible under the
provision of this chapter to be designated for burial in such space at the date of such person's
death. (1991 Code § 5.5-13)
B. Rights Upon Interment: Whenever an interment of the remains of any person is made in a space,
the space thereby becomes inalienable and shall be held as the space of the interred person.
(1991 Code § 5.5-14)
8-4-12: COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS:
All interments, disinterments and removals are subject to the orders and laws of the properly
constituted authorities of the city, Custer County and the state of Oklahoma. (1991 Code § 5.5-15)
8-4-13: REGULATIONS CONCERNING INTERMENTS:
All earth interments shall be in a liner or vault of concrete or steel of a type approved by the cemetery
supervisor, except in the case of a baby or an indigent, in which a wood box may be used. When an
interment is to be made in a lot, the location of such interment shall be designated by the lot owner.
Should the lot owner fail or neglect to make such designation, the cemetery reserves the right to make
the interment in a location designated by the cemetery supervisor. No more than the remains of one
body shall be interred in any one space, vault, crypt or niche, except in the case of a mother and a
stillborn child; provided, however, if written permission is given by the owner of a space or, if the owner
is deceased, by the owner's heirs, permitting more than the remains of one person to occupy a space,
vault, crypt or niche, an exception will be made. Such exception shall permit no more than one regular
interment and one cremains or two (2) cremains in any one space, vault, crypt or niche. (1991 Code
§ 5.5-16; amd. Ord. 757A, 5-19-2015)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 193/382
8-4-14: NOTICE TO CITY; RESTRICTIONS ON CERTAIN DAYS:
The cemetery supervisor must be given no less than twenty four (24) hours' notice prior to any
interment. At least one week's notice must be given for disinterment or removal. In no event shall
interments and disinterments be permitted on Sundays or any of the holidays as set forth in section 8-
4-7 of this chapter, or any other days which hereafter may be designated by the city council, except as
may be provided in said section 8-4-7 of this chapter. (1991 Code § 5.5-17; amd. Ord. 757A, 5-19-
2015)
8-4-15: FEES AND CHARGES:
The city shall furnish all equipment required for opening and closing a grave. Service fees for the use
of equipment and labor shall be established by the city council, and such fees must be paid prior to
interment, entombment, inurnment, disinterment or removal, unless otherwise provided. In the event
any opening and/or closing is required on Saturday, Sunday or a holiday, there shall be a special
charge added to the regular fee which will be equal to one-half (1/2) the regular fee. (1991 Code § 5.5-
18)
8-4-16: NONLIABILITY OF CITY; PRESENTATION OF INTERMENT PERMIT:
The city is not liable for the interment permit, nor for the identity of the remains brought for interment,
nor for the embalming of the body. No interment shall be made unless an interment permit is
presented to the cemetery supervisor or his designee prior to interment. (1991 Code § 5.5-19; amd.
Ord. 757A, 5-19-2015)
8-4-17: FUNERAL PROCESSIONS:
Funeral processions entering the cemetery shall be under the control of the cemetery supervisor;
provided, that funeral directors shall be present to conduct services. (1991 Code § 5.5-20; amd. Ord.
757A, 5-19-2015)
8-4-18: DISINTERMENTS:
A. Filing Application; Consent Required: Caskets containing remains, once interred, will not be opened
or removed without the written consent of the legally designated representative of the deceased
(personal representative as designated by will, estate executor, spouse, etc.) and/or an order from
a court of competent jurisdiction. All removals and reinterments shall not be done until an
application for disinterment has been filed with, and approval obtained from, the state health
department. A licensed funeral director shall be present at the disinterment. Care shall be
exercised in making a removal. The city shall not be liable for any damages which may result from
a removal.
B. Remains Of Unknown Person Discovered: When the bodily remains of an unknown person are
discovered in an unidentified and unmarked grave, the remains may be removed to some other
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 194/382
gravesite within the cemetery, at the expense of the city, if no record exists as to a sale or
conveyance of the lot and the city is without knowledge that a body had been buried in the
gravesite, in the event the lot is sold to another person. An application for approval of the
disinterment and removal of the bodily remains shall be first filed with, and approval obtained from,
the state health department. (1991 Code § 5.5-21)
8-4-19: CARE OF GROUNDS; CHANGES; TAPPING OF WATER LINES:
A. City Authority; Fee: The city shall have the right to make any changes to the cemetery deemed
necessary by the city as to such things as grading, roads and utility lines without notice or approval
of space owners. It shall be unlawful for any person to tap into any water line at the cemetery
without specific authorization from the cemetery supervisor. A fee for tapping said water line may
be set by city council. (1991 Code § 5.5-23; amd. Ord. 757A, 5-19-2015)
B. Permit Required: Before a water system of any kind is installed on a lot or lots, a permit must be
obtained at the building inspector's office. (1991 Code § 5.5-23)
8-4-20: MARKERS; PERMITS:
A. Permanent and temporary memorials of cement, artificial stone, composition, wood, tin or iron shall
not be permitted. All markers, monuments, mausoleums or vaults, which part or any part that
shows above the surface, must be made of natural marble, granite, or bronze, and shall be of first
grade material and carry a certificate of guarantee as to quality and workmanship. All concrete or
part concrete burial vaults or so called individual mausoleums, all steel, copper or bronze vaults,
not being made of natural marble or granite shall be buried underground with at least eighteen
inches (18") of earth covering them, except on lots now having said work.
B. One marker or monument shall be permitted for each space, and such marker or monument shall
be placed at the head of the grave, except in the case of a government marker which may be
placed at the foot of the grave, if a family or companion marker or monument is at the head of the
grave. No individual marker or monument may be placed on a base with a width larger than five
feet (5') unless the lot owner has adjacent spaces that are not intended for burial. No marker or
monument shall be placed in the cemetery until a permit has been purchased from the city clerk
and the cemetery supervisor has noted on the space where the marker is to be placed. Charges
for the placing of markers shall be set from time to time by the city council.
C. Flat markers only may be placed in the area designated as "veterans area" and in those areas
restricted to flat markers and so designated on the official cemetery map on file in the city clerk's
office.
D. Any markers or monuments placed prior to burial or interment that interfere with the opening of a
grave shall be moved by the city and returned to its original placement by the city. The owner of
the lot shall be liable for the actual cost of moving the marker or monument as determined by the
city. The city will not be held liable for any damage incurred in the removal and replacement
process.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 195/382
E. In the event that "military markers" are delivered to the city for placement on a lot, the city shall
place or set the marker only upon receipt of a marker placement fee as established by the city
council. (Ord. 757A, 5-19-2015)
8-4-21: REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS WITHIN CEMETERY:
A. Grave Decorations: Grave decorations of all kinds shall be removed when, in the judgment of the
cemetery supervisor, they do not conform to the decorum of the cemetery. Decorations shall be
permitted for Memorial Day, Easter and Christmas and be allowed to remain for twenty one (21)
days, but must be removed within thirty (30) days after the holiday or sooner if notified by
publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Decorations not removed by the owner
within the specified time shall be removed by the cemetery supervisor or his authorized personnel.
The cemetery shall not be responsible for the loss of any plantings or decorations by any cause
whatsoever. (1991 Code § 5.5-22; amd. Ord. 757A, 5-19-2015)
B. Driving Within Cemetery: No person shall drive any vehicle within the cemetery, except upon the
driveways prepared and designated for that purpose. (1991 Code § 5.5-25)
C. Desecration Or Injury To Cemetery, Graves, Markers: It shall be unlawful for any person to
desecrate or injure the cemetery, or any grave, tomb, gravestone, monument, fence, tree or
shrubbery therein; or to break, cut, injure or disturb any natural vegetation; or to harm in any
manner any wildlife within the cemetery. (1991 Code § 5.5-26)
D. Children; Pets; Food: No child under fifteen (15) years of age shall be permitted in the cemetery
unless accompanied by an adult. Pets and food shall be prohibited in the cemetery. (1991 Code
§ 5.5-27)
E. Plantings: No person shall plant or place any shrubbery, plants, flowers, grass or trees without the
approval of the cemetery supervisor. (1991 Code § 5.5-28; amd. Ord. 757A, 5-19-2015)
F. Interference With Funerals: It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere, without legal cause, with
the proper conduct of a funeral or with the burying or exhuming of a body in the Clinton Cemetery.
(1991 Code § 5.5-29)
8-4-22: RULES AND REGULATIONS, CITY AUTHORITY:
The city may, and it hereby expressly reserves the right, at any time or times, to adopt new rules or
regulations, to amend, alter and/or repeal any rule, regulation and/or section, paragraph and/or
sentence in these rules or regulations. Such new or amended rules and regulations shall be binding
on the owners of all lots or burial spaces regardless of the date such owner acquired title. (1991 Code
§ 5.5-31)
8-4-23: TEMPORARY MODIFICATION OF PROVISIONS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 196/382
The city hereby recognizes that cases may arise in which the strict enforcement of the provisions
hereof may impose unnecessary hardship. The city council shall have the authority to make
exceptions to the provisions of this chapter by resolution upon a finding by the city council that such is
necessary to prevent hardship. (1991 Code § 5.5-30)
8-4-24: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as
provided by section 1-4-1 of this code. (1991 Code § 5.5-32)
Chapter 5
LAKE CLINTON AND CLINTON WATER DISTRICT
8-5-1: APPLICATION OF STATE LAW:
The laws of the state relating to fishing and boating shall, except as herein otherwise provided, govern
and regulate all such activities within the Clinton water district. This includes laws and regulations
relating to species and number of fish to be taken which shall be the same as are prescribed from time
to time by state law. (1991 Code § 15-28; amd. 2007 Code)
8-5-2: HUNTING AND FISHING:
A. State License Or Permit Required:
1. No person shall be allowed to hunt or fish at any point within the Clinton water district without
securing therefor a state license or permit and complying with all state laws and ordinances
relating thereto.
2. Each licensee shall carry his license or permit upon his person and produce the same upon
demand of any city employee authorized to require the same. Persons excused or exempted
from license requirements under state laws are also excused or exempted to the same degree
by the city. (1991 Code § 15-41)
B. Selling Fish And Game Prohibited: No person shall sell or offer for sale any fish caught by him from
Clinton Lake or any game killed within the Clinton water district. (1991 Code § 15-42)
C. Limitation On Species And Number Of Fish: Regulations of the state covering the species and
numbers of fish and water life that may be taken shall apply to the subject water districts. (1991
Code § 15-43)
D. Fish Bait: It shall be unlawful to use any bait other than live or artificial bait, which shall include fish,
worms and insects suitable for fish bait. No bait commonly known as stench or "stink" bait shall be
used. What is commonly known as "dough" bait may be used. (1991 Code § 15-44)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 197/382
8-5-3: BOATING:
A. Lake Opened To Boating: Lake Clinton is hereby opened to the public for boating. (1991 Code
§ 15-61)
B. Rules, Regulations And Restrictions:
1. Swimming, Skiing: There shall be no swimming, skiing or jet skiing on Lake Clinton. (2007
Code)
2. Sailboats Prohibited: Sailboats are prohibited on Lake Clinton. (1991 Code § 15-65)
3. Boat Operation By Children: No child under the age of fifteen (15) years shall be allowed to
operate a boat upon the lake unless accompanied by his parent or guardian. (1991 Code § 15-
66)
4. Firearms: No firearm shall be carried or transported in or upon any boat upon the lake except
when the same is being used for hunting as provided by this chapter. (1991 Code § 15-67)
5. Throwing Food Or Refuse Into Lake: No scrap of food, waste paper or refuse of any kind, or any
other substance, refuse or effete matter tending to contaminate the waters of the lake, shall be
thrown or deposited in the lake. (1991 Code § 15-70)
6. Racing And Speeding Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to race or speed in motorboats upon any
city owned or controlled waters. The entire lake shall be considered a "no wake zone". (1991
Code § 15-71; amd. 2007 Code)
C. Transporting Persons For Hire: No person shall operate or use any boat for transporting
passengers for hire upon the lake unless authorized to do so by written permission from the city.
(1991 Code § 15-69)
8-5-4: FIREARMS PROHIBITED:
No person shall use any rifle, revolver or pistol within the Clinton water district; provided, however, this
shall not apply to employees of the city specially authorized to use the same. (1991 Code § 15-27)
8-5-5: USE OF BOATHOUSE RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful to use any boathouse constructed upon the Lake Clinton site for human habitation,
either temporary or permanent, and no boathouse shall be used for camping purposes. (1991 Code
§ 15-29)
8-5-6: PENALTY:
Unless stated otherwise, violations of this chapter are punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this
code. (1991 Code § 15-26)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 198/382
Chapter 6
WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES
8-6-1: PURPOSE:
The purposes of these regulations for wireless telecommunications facilities are:
A. To facilitate the provision of wireless telecommunications services throughout the city;
B. To enhance the ability to provide wireless telecommunications services to the community quickly,
effectively and efficiently;
C. To prohibit the construction of towers in all zones except C-4 and industrial districts;
D. To minimize the total number of towers in the community;
E. To encourage the joint use of new and existing tower locations;
F. To ensure that towers are located in areas that minimize adverse impacts;
G. To ensure towers and antennas are configured in a way that minimizes adverse visual impacts by
careful design, appropriate siting, landscape screening, and innovative camouflaging techniques;
H. To encourage the attachment of antennas to existing structures;
I. To consider public health and safety of wireless telecommunications facilities;
J. To avoid damage to adjacent properties from tower failure through careful engineering and locating
of tower structures; and
K. To protect residential areas and lands by minimizing adverse impacts of towers. (Ord. 836, 7-11-
2000)
8-6-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section:
ACCESSORY SUPPORT FACILITIES: Support buildings, structures and equipment cabinets for
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 199/382
telecommunications facilities containing electrical and mechanical equipment and devices used for the
reception of or transmission of voice, data, image, graphic and video programming information
between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite or similar
facilities.
ALTERNATIVE TOWER STRUCTURE: Manmade trees, clock towers, bell steeples, building
structures or building equipment normally maintained above the roofline of a structure, light poles and
similar alternative design mounting structures. An alternative tower structure must be compatible with
the natural setting and surrounding structures, and must camouflage or conceal the presence of
antennas and/or towers. This term also includes any antenna or antenna array attached to the
alternative tower structure.
ANTENNA: Any exterior transmitting and/or receiving devices mounted on a tower, building or
structure and used in communications that radiate and/or capture electromagnetic waves, digital
signals, analog signals, radio frequencies (excluding radar signals), wireless telecommunications
signals or other communications signals.
BACKHAUL NETWORK: The lines, microwave, etc., that connect a provider's tower/cell sites to one
or more cellular telephone switching offices, and/or long distance providers, or the public switched
telephone network.
FAA: Federal aviation administration.
FCC: Federal communications commission.
TOWER: Any structure designed and constructed primarily for the purpose of supporting one or more
antennas, including self-supporting lattice towers, guy towers, or monopole towers. The term includes
radio and television transmission towers, microwave towers, common carrier towers, cellular
telephone towers, and other similar structures. This term also includes any antenna or antenna array
attached to the tower structure.
TOWER HEIGHT: When referring to a tower or other alternative tower structure, the distance
measured from the lowest point within ten feet (10') of the structure to the highest point on the tower
or other alternative tower structure, including the base pad.
WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES: The plant, equipment and property, including, but
not limited to, cables, wires, conduits, ducts, pedestals, antennas, towers, alternative tower structures,
electronics and other appurtenances used to transmit, receive, distribute, provide or offer wireless
telecommunications services.
WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICE: The providing or offering for rent, sale or lease, or
in exchange for other value received, of the transmittal or reception of voice, data, image, graphic and
video programming information between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser,
microwave, radio, satellite or similar facilities, with or without benefit of any closed transmission
medium. (Ord. 836, 7-11-2000)
8-6-3: PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS; VIOLATION:
Wireless telecommunications facilities shall be regulated and permitted pursuant to this chapter and
the zoning ordinances of the city.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 200/382
A. Permit: A wireless telecommunications facility shall obtain a permit as a condition for the siting,
construction or operation of the facility.
B. Exceptions: These regulations shall apply to all towers and antennas as defined, except:
1. Any tower not more than seventy feet (70') in height, owned and operated by a federally
licensed amateur radio station operator, if it is used exclusively as a receive only facility.
2. Any antenna collocated on an existing telecommunications facility, except as expressly provided
in this chapter.
3. A wireless telecommunications facility located or collocated on property, which is owned by the
city and designated by the city as a site suitable for location of a wireless telecommunications
facility.
C. Violation A Nuisance; Injunctive Relief: Any violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a
nuisance. In addition to any other relief or penalty provided by law, the city may apply to district
court for an injunction to prohibit the continuation of any violation of this chapter. (Ord. 836, 7-11-
2000)
8-6-4: PERMIT APPROVAL PROCESS; PERMIT FEES:
A. Notice To Adjacent Property Owners:
1. Except for a proposed wireless telecommunications facility which will collocate on an existing
tower, the applicant for a wireless telecommunications facility permit shall provide the city clerk
with a certified list of all property owners within three hundred feet (300') of the outer boundary of
the property proposed for location of the facility.
2. The city clerk will send each property owner a notice describing the boundaries of the property
included in the application, explain the character and dimensions of the proposed facility and
give the office of the city clerk as the address for the property owners to submit written
comments to the applicant.
3. The notice shall include a drawing or other representation of the visual aspects of the proposed
facility. The notice shall also contain the date, which shall be not less than fifteen (15) days after
the mailing date, set for consideration of the application by the planning and zoning board.
B. Plans, Maps And Inventories:
1. The city requires the following specific information about the tower site and the applicant's
system design for current and future facilities within the corporate boundaries:
a. An inventory and contour map of existing facilities that are within the city including specific
information about the location, height, and design of each wireless telecommunications facility,
wireless telecommunications tower.
b. A vicinity map and scaled set of plans identifying impacts on the surrounding built
environment.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 201/382
c. An engineer's report, certifying that the proposed wireless telecommunications facility is
compatible for collocation by a minimum of three (3) users.
2. The city typically provides that its administrator will develop, update and maintain an inventory of
towers and antennas. The telecommunications service providers are required to register and pay
an annual inspection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
C. Permit Fees:
1. An initial permit of five hundred dollars ($500.00) is required for the city to review the application
to construct. This shall be in lieu of a building permit.
2. An annual permit of one hundred dollars ($100.00) is required to be paid in January of each
year. At the time the permit is renewed, the applicant shall submit a current copy of the
applicant's FCC license, and FAA permits, if applicable. (Ord. 836, 7-11-2000)
8-6-5: COLLOCATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Feasibility; Conditions: All applicants for wireless telecommunications facility permits shall collocate
on an existing facility, if it is feasible to do so. An existing facility shall be deemed to be available to
the applicant for collocation if the facility is within one mile of the proposed site, space is available
on the facility, and the facility owner will lease space to the applicant at a reasonable market rate.
1. If the applicant finds that collocation is not feasible, it shall submit to the city a written statement
of the reasons for the infeasibility. The city may retain a technical expert in the field of radio
frequency (RF) engineering to determine whether collocation at the site is feasible. The cost for
such a technical expert will be at the expense of the applicant.
2. The city may deny the permit unless the applicant demonstrates to the city by substantial
evidence, such as propagation maps or drive test data, that existing wireless communication
facilities cannot accommodate the applicant's proposed antenna.
B. Tower Use By Other Providers: A wireless telecommunications tower shall not be permitted unless
the owner of the proposed tower certifies to the city that the tower is available for use by other
wireless telecommunication service providers on a reasonable and nondiscriminatory basis.
Towers shall be designed and built to accommodate a minimum of three (3) wireless
telecommunications facilities.
C. Master Plans Required: To facilitate collocation and coordination of wireless telecommunication
sites, all wireless telecommunication tower providers shall provide the city with their respective
master plans. Said plans shall include detailed maps, showing the locations of all wireless
telecommunications towers serving any portion of the city. All carriers in said towers shall provide:
address, street location, latitude and longitude, emergency contact and number, marketing contact
and number.
D. Annual Updates To Documents: Providers shall also provide the city with any updates to the above
documents annually. (Ord. 836, 7-11-2000)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 202/382
8-6-6: TELECOMMUNICATION FACILITIES STANDARDS:
A. Attractive Nuisance: Those locations that are well suited for placement of towers on municipal
property require fencing or other safety barriers as approved by the city.
B. Compatibility:
1. Wireless telecommunication facilities shall either maintain a galvanized steel finish or, subject to
applicable standards of the FAA, be painted, so as to reduce visual obtrusiveness. Dish
antennas will be of a neutral, nonreflective color with no logos.
2. The exterior of equipment buildings and/or metal equipment cabinets visible from residential
areas or public rights of way must have a neutral aggregate finish or be painted to reflect the
color and character of adjoining structures or blend with adjacent landscaping and other
surroundings.
C. Design: At the wireless telecommunications facility, the design of the buildings and related
structures used in conjunction with wireless telecommunications facilities shall, to the extent
possible, use materials, colors, textures, screening and landscaping that will blend the facilities to
the natural setting and the built environment.
D. Guy Wires: Guy wires must be anchored no closer than twenty five feet (25') from any property line.
Guy wires shall not cross or encroach any overhead telephone or electric power lines.
E. Height: Towers for two (2) or more users: Not more than two hundred fifty feet (250').
F. Interference: Antennas (amateur or commercial) shall not interfere with radio or television reception
of adjoining property owners, and shall comply with all regulations of the federal communications
commission (FCC).
G. Landscaping: Landscaping shall be determined in negotiation with the tower owner on a case by
case basis.
H. Lighting: Illumination of the towers is prohibited, except as required by the FAA. Strobes shall not
be used for nighttime lighting. Any required lighting shall be directed upward and away from
adjoining properties. In addition, the ground level security lighting shall not be more than twenty
feet (20') in height.
I. Screening: The base of the tower and any accessory support facilities shall be screened from view
with a security fence, which shall be a minimum of eight feet (8') in height. The materials of the
fence shall be compatible with the primary uses of the surrounding property.
J. Security Fence: The city requires a fence of not less than eight feet (8') and no greater than ten feet
(10') to completely enclose the tower and anchored locations of guy wires, if used. The fence must
be located within the front, side and rear yards.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 203/382
K. Tower Setbacks And Fall Zones: Setback: A minimum of one hundred fifty feet (150') from the
nearest residential structure.
L. Signs: Lettering, signs, symbols, images or trademarks large enough to be legible to occupants or
vehicular traffic on any adjacent roadway shall not be placed on or affixed to any part of a tower,
antenna array or antenna, other than as required by FCC regulations.
M. Spacing: No tower shall be closer than one mile from another tower, such distance being measured
as a horizontal from tower to tower. Any new telecommunications tower in excess of one hundred
eighty feet (180') (55 m) in height must be located a minimum of one mile (1.6 km) from any
existing tower in excess of one hundred eighty feet (180') (55 m) in height.
N. Support Facilities: Support facilities can be no more than twelve feet (12') in height per user.
Minimum setback requirements of the zoning district apply to the accessory support facilities. (Ord.
836, 7-11-2000)
8-6-7: ALTERNATIVE STRUCTURES STANDARDS:
A wireless telecommunications facility may be permitted on an alternative tower structure at least thirty
feet (30') tall under the following conditions, which shall be in addition to the requirements of sections
8-6-6 and 8-6-8 of this chapter:
A. The facility and its accessory support facilities comply with all zoning requirements applicable to the
alternate structure and the provisions of section 8-6-6 of this chapter.
B. If the facility or an accessory support facility is located upon the roof of a structure, each such
facility shall be set back a distance at least equal to the height of the wireless telecommunications
facility unless the facilities are screened or camouflaged in a manner that is compatible with the
surrounding property. The top of the antenna or other facility shall not be more than thirty percent
(30%) of the height of the alternate structure, or seventy five feet (75') whichever is less.
C. The alternative structure must be similar in color, scale and character to adjoining buildings or
structures or blend with the landscaping and other surroundings immediately adjacent to them so
as to generally avoid the creation of unique visual objects that stand out in the environment.
D. Prior to the installation of any building/roof mounted wireless telecommunications facility, the
applicant shall furnish to the city an engineer's certification that the structure will support and not
be adversely affected by the proposed antenna and accessory support facility or equipment. (Ord.
836, 7-11-2000)
8-6-8: SPECIFIC STANDARDS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 204/382
A. Federal And State Standards: All wireless telecommunications facilities shall be erected and
operated in compliance with current federal communication commission (FCC) and federal aviation
administration (FAA) rules and regulations and other applicable federal, state and local standards.
B. Environmental Standards: Municipalities address a variety of environmental concerns by:
1. Prohibiting siting in certain areas; and
2. Controlling the impact of a telecommunication facility on and in the area of the site. Examples:
a. Wireless telecommunication facilities shall comply with FCC, FAA, NEPA, and all other
applicable federal and state regulations, and a letter from a certified engineer so stating is
required.
b. Ground mounted equipment for personal wireless service facilities shall not generate noise in
excess of fifty (50) dB at the property line. Roof mounted or side mounted equipment for
personal wireless service facilities shall not generate noise in excess of fifty (50) dB at ground
level at the base of the building closest to the antenna.
C. Soil Reports: Soil reports will be met with an engineer's certificate.
D. Standards: Standards will be met with an engineer's certificate. (Ord. 836, 7-11-2000)
E. Wind Standards: Telecommunications facilities shall be designed and engineered to withstand wind
loadings and other design standards as defined by ANSI for Custer County. (Ord. 836, 7-11-2000;
amd. 2007 Code)
8-6-9: PERMIT CONDITIONS:
A. Abandonment; Bond; Removal:
1. A wireless telecommunications service provider shall post a bond or other security sufficient to
pay for the removal of any abandoned facility.
2. No owner or occupant of property within the city shall permit, leave or cause to be left on said
property any wireless telecommunications facility which has been abandoned or discontinued for
use.
3. The provider shall remove its facility within one year of the date that it discontinues its use of the
facility. If the provider fails to remove the facility within the required time, the facility shall be
deemed to be abandoned. The city shall have authority to enter the premises and remove the
abandoned facilities. All costs of removal that exceed the amount of the bond ($20,000.00)
posted for that purpose shall be collected from the provider or property owner in the manner
provided for summary abatement of nuisances. This requirement shall apply to collocated
facilities unless the collocation agreement provides for the removal of abandoned facilities by the
tower operator.
B. Defective Facilities: Defective or unsafe antennas, wireless telecommunication towers or wireless
telecommunication facilities must be repaired or removed within one year at the owner or
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 205/382
operator's expense.
C. Nonconforming Use: The owner of an existing wireless telecommunications structure (tower) may,
by right, upon written notice to the city, replace the tower with a new tower if the new tower
structure complies with all applicable sections of this chapter, and: 1) is specifically designed to
accommodate additional antenna arrays; 2) is not more than twenty feet (20') higher than the
structure being replaced; and 3) is not more than fifty feet (50') from the location of the structure
being replaced. (Ord. 836, 7-11-2000)
Chapter 7
AIRPORT ZONING
8-7-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the CLINTON MUNICIPAL AIRPORT ZONING
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires:
AIRPORT: Clinton municipal airport.
AIRPORT ELEVATION: One thousand six hundred thirteen feet (1,613') above mean sea level.
APPROACH SURFACE: A surface longitudinally centered on the extended runway centerline,
extending outward and upward from the end of the primary surface and at the same slope as the
approach zone height limitation slope set forth in section 8-7-7 of this chapter. In plan, the perimeter of
the approach surface coincides with the perimeter of the approach zone.
APPROACH, TRANSITIONAL, HORIZONTAL, AND CONICAL ZONES: These zones are set forth in
section 8-7-6 of this chapter.
BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT: A board consisting of five (5) members appointed by the city council as
provided for in 3 Oklahoma Statutes section 110.
CONICAL SURFACE: A surface extending outward and upward from the periphery of the horizontal
surface at a slope of twenty to one (20:1) for a horizontal distance of four thousand feet (4,000').
HAZARD TO AIR NAVIGATION: An obstruction determined to have a substantial adverse effect on
the safe and efficient utilization of the navigable airspace.
HEIGHT: For the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in this chapter and
shown on the zoning map, the datum shall be mean sea level elevation unless otherwise specified.
HORIZONTAL SURFACE: A horizontal plane one hundred fifty feet (150') above the established
airport elevation, the perimeter of which in plan coincides with the perimeter of the horizontal zone.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 206/382
NONCONFORMING USE: Any preexisting structure, object of natural growth, or use of land which is
inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter or an amendment thereto.
OBSTRUCTION: Any structure, growth, or other object, including a mobile object, which exceeds a
limiting height set forth in section 8-7-7 of this chapter.
PERSON: An individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, joint stock association,
or governmental entity; includes a trustee, a receiver, an assignee, or a similar representative of any
of them.
PRIMARY SURFACE: A surface longitudinally centered on a runway. When the runway has a
specially prepared hard surface, the primary surface extends two hundred feet (200') beyond each
end of that runway; when the runway has no specially prepared hard surface, or planned hard surface,
the primary surface ends at each end of that runway. The width of the primary surface is set forth in
section 8-7-6 of this chapter. The elevation of any point on the primary surface is the same as the
elevation of the nearest point on the runway centerline.
RUNWAY: A defined area on an airport prepared for landing and takeoff of aircraft along its length.
STRUCTURE: An object, including a mobile object, constructed or installed by man, including, but
without limitation, buildings, towers, cranes, smokestacks, earth formation, and overhead transmission
lines.
TRANSITIONAL SURFACES: These surfaces extend outward at ninety degree (90°) angles to the
runway centerline and the runway centerline extended at a slope of seven feet (7') horizontally for
each foot vertically from the sides of the primary and approach surfaces to where they intersect the
horizontal and conical surfaces.
TREE: Any object of natural growth.
UTILITY RUNWAY: A runway that is constructed for and intended to be used by propeller driven
aircraft of twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) pounds' maximum gross weight, and less.
VISUAL RUNWAY: A runway intended solely for the operation of aircraft using visual approach
procedures. (Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-3: ENFORCEMENT; SUBMISSION OF APPLICATIONS:
A. Enforcement: It shall be the duty of the city to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed
herein.
B. Applications: Applications for permits and variances shall be made to the city upon a form
published for that purpose. Applications required by this chapter to be submitted to the city shall be
promptly considered and granted or denied. Application for action by the board of adjustment shall
be forthwith transmitted by the city. (Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-4: BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT:
A. Powers: The board of adjustment shall have and exercise the following powers:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 207/382
1. To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by
the city, in the enforcement of this chapter;
2. To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this chapter upon which such board of
adjustment, under such regulations, may be required to pass; and
3. To hear and decide specific variances.
B. Board Action: The board of adjustment shall make written findings of fact and conclusions of law
giving the facts upon which it acted and its legal conclusions from such facts in reversing,
affirming, or modifying any order, requirement, decision, or determination which comes before it
under the provisions of this chapter.
C. Majority Vote Of Members: The concurring vote of a majority of the members of the board of
adjustment shall be sufficient to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the
city or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under this
chapter, or to effect variation to this chapter. (Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-5: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; VARIANCES:
A. Future Uses:
1. Permit Required; Conditions And Exceptions: Except as specifically provided in subsections
A1a, A1b, and A1c of this section, no material change shall be made in the use of land, no
structure shall be erected or otherwise established, and no tree shall be planted in any zone
hereby created unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted. Each
application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient
particularity to permit it to be determined whether the resulting use, structure, or tree would
conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the
permit shall be granted. No permit for a use inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter shall
be granted unless a variance has been approved in accordance with subsection D of this
section.
a. In the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and conical zone, no permit shall be
required for any tree or structure less than seventy five feet (75') of vertical height above the
ground, except when, because of terrain, land contour, or topographic features, such tree or
structure would extend above the height limits prescribed for such zones.
b. In areas lying within the limits of the approach zones, but at a horizontal distance of not less
than four thousand two hundred feet (4,200') from each end of the runway, no permit shall be
required for any tree or structure less than seventy five feet (75') of vertical height above the
ground, except when such tree or structure would extend above the height limit prescribed for
such approach zones.
c. In the areas lying within the limits of the transition zones beyond the perimeter of the
horizontal zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than seventy five feet
(75') of vertical height above the ground, except when such tree or structure, because of
terrain, land contour, or topographic features, would extend above the height limit prescribed
for such transition zones.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 208/382
2. Height Limits: Nothing contained in any of the foregoing exceptions shall be construed as
permitting or intending to permit any construction or alteration of any structure, or growth of any
tree in excess of any of the height limits established by this chapter, except as set forth in
subsection 8-7-7E of this chapter.
B. Existing Uses: No permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an
obstruction or permit a nonconforming use, structure, or tree to become a greater hazard to air
navigation than it was on the effective date hereof, or any amendments thereto, or than it is when
the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for such a permit shall be
granted.
C. Nonconforming Uses Abandoned Or Destroyed: Whenever the city determines that a
nonconforming tree or structure has been abandoned or more than eighty percent (80%) torn
down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such
structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning
regulations.
D. Variances:
1. Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any
tree, or use property, not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this chapter, may
apply to the board of adjustment for a variance from such regulations. The application for
variance shall be accompanied by a determination from the federal aviation administration as to
the effect of the proposal on the operation of air navigation facilities and the safe, efficient use of
navigable air space. Such variances shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal
application or enforcement of the regulations will result in unnecessary hardship, and relief
granted will not be contrary to the public interest, will not create a hazard to air navigation, will do
substantial justice, and will be in accordance with the spirit of this chapter.
2. Additionally, no application for variance to the requirements of this chapter may be considered
by the board of adjustment unless a copy of the application has been furnished to the airport
manager for advice as to the aeronautical effects of the variance. If the airport manager does not
respond to the application within fifteen (15) days after receipt, the board of adjustment may act
on its own to grant or deny said application.
E. Obstruction Marking And Lighting: Any permit or variance granted may, if such action is deemed
advisable to effectuate the purpose of this chapter and be responsible in the circumstances, be so
conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree in question to install, operate, and
maintain, at the owner's expense, such markings and lights as may be necessary. If deemed
proper by the board of adjustment, this condition may be modified to require the owner to permit
the city, at its own expense, to install, operate, and maintain the necessary markings and lights.
(Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-6: AIRPORT ZONES:
In order to carry out the provisions of this chapter, there are hereby created and established certain
zones which include all of the land lying beneath the approach surfaces, transitional surfaces,
horizontal surfaces, and conical surfaces as they apply to the Clinton municipal airport. Such zones
are shown on the Clinton municipal airport zoning map consisting of one sheet, prepared by Glenn
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 209/382
Briggs & Associates, Inc., and dated October 1, 1998, which is referred to in this chapter and made a
part hereof by reference. An area located in more than one of the following zones is considered to be
only in the zone with the more restrictive height limitation. The various zones are hereby established
and defined as follows:
A. Utility Runway Visual Approach Zone: The inner edge of this approach zone coincides with the
width of the primary surface and is two hundred fifty feet (250') wide. The approach zone expands
outward uniformly to a width of one thousand two hundred fifty feet (1,250') at a horizontal distance
of five thousand feet (5,000') from the primary surface. Its centerline is the continuation of the
centerline of the runway.
B. Transitional Zones: The transitional zones are the areas beneath the transitional surfaces.
C. Horizontal Zone: The horizontal zone is established by swinging arcs of five thousand feet (5,000')
radii from the center of each end of the primary surface of each runway and connecting the
adjacent arcs by drawing lines tangent to those arcs. The horizontal zone does not include the
approach and transitional zones.
D. Conical Zone: The conical zone is established as the area that commences at the periphery of the
horizontal zone and extends outward therefrom a horizontal distance of four thousand feet (4,000').
(Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-7: AIRPORT ZONE HEIGHT LIMITATIONS:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no structure shall be erected, altered, or maintained, and
no tree shall be allowed to grow in any zone created by this chapter to a height in excess of the
applicable height limit herein established for such zone. Such applicable height limitations are hereby
established for each of the zones in question as follows:
A. Utility Runway Visual Approach Zone: Slopes twenty feet (20') outward for each foot upward
beginning at the end of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and extending to a
horizontal distance of five thousand feet (5,000') along the extended runway centerline.
B. Transitional Zones: Slope seven feet (7') outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of
and at the same elevation as the primary surface and the approach surface, and extending to a
height of one hundred fifty feet (150') above the airport elevation which is one thousand six
hundred thirteen feet (1,613') above mean sea level. In addition to the foregoing, there are
established height limits sloping seven feet (7') outward for each foot upward beginning at the
sides of and at the same elevation as the approach surface, and extending to where they intersect
the conical surface.
C. Horizontal Zone: Established at one hundred fifty feet (150') above the airport elevation or at a
height of two hundred fifty feet (250') above mean sea level.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 210/382
D. Conical Zone: Slopes twenty feet (20') outward for each foot upward beginning at the periphery of
the horizontal zone and at one hundred fifty feet (150') above the airport elevation and extending to
a height of three hundred fifty feet (350') above the airport elevation.
E. Excepted Height Limitations: Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting the
construction or maintenance of any structure, or growth of any tree to a height up to fifty feet (50')
above the surface of the land. (Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-8: USE RESTRICTIONS:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, no use may be made of land or water within any
zone established by this chapter in such a manner as to create electrical interference with navigational
signals or radio communication between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for pilots to distinguish
between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes of pilots using the airport, impair visibility
in the vicinity of the airport, create bird strike hazards, or otherwise in any way endanger or interfere
with the landing, takeoff, or maneuvering of aircraft intending to use the airport. (Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-9: NONCONFORMING USES:
A. Regulations Not Retroactive: The regulations prescribed by this chapter shall not be construed to
require the removal, lowering, or other change or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming
to the regulations as of the effective date hereof, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of a
nonconforming use. Nothing contained herein shall require any change in the construction,
alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior
to the effective date hereof, and is diligently prosecuted.
B. Marking And Lighting: Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, the owner of any existing
nonconforming structure or tree is hereby required to permit the installation, operation, and
maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the city, to
indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport the presence of such airport
obstruction. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of
the city. (Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-10: MORE STRINGENT PROVISIONS GOVERN:
Where there exists a conflict between any of the regulations or limitations prescribed in this chapter
and any other regulations applicable to the same area, whether the conflict be with respect to the
height of structures or trees, and the use of land, or any other matter, the more stringent limitation or
requirement shall govern and prevail. (Ord. 812, 11-3-1998)
8-7-11: APPEALS:
A. Right To Appeal: Any person aggrieved or any taxpayer affected by any decision of the city, made
in the administration of this chapter, may appeal to the board of adjustment.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 211/382
B. Time Limitation; Filing Of Notice Of Appeal: All appeals hereunder must be taken within a
