ARTICLE A. TECHNICAL STANDARDS1
10-2A-1: CONFORMANCE WITH NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE:
All electrical construction, all materials, and all appliances used in connection with electrical work, and
the operation and arrangement of all electrical apparatus, shall be in conformity with the current
edition of a certain document, one copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk and copies
available, marked and designated as the 2014 national electrical code as published by the
International Code Council, Inc., is hereby adopted as the electrical code of the city for the control of
buildings and structures as herein provided. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of such publication are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if
fully set out in this section. (Ord. 971, 7-5-2016)
10-2A-2: THIRTY DAY PERMITS:
For good and sufficient reason, the electrical inspector may grant permits for a period of thirty (30)
days with the privilege of extending same upon the payment of a fee established by ordinance for
each thirty (30) days. (1991 Code § 5-127)
10-2A-3: SPECIFIC STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS:
A. Conduits: All electric wiring used to carry current for light, heat or power placed in or on all buildings
or additions erected within the fire limits of the city shall be installed in approved metal conduit or
metal molding. In all cases within the corporate limits, there shall be a rigid conduit into the meter
from the outside and from the meter to the first opening. (1991 Code § 5-117)
B. Rough In Work: All "roughing in" work shall include service switch branch blocks or panel boards
and cabinets. When installing conduit, metal molding or armored cable, all connections must be
free from grounds and left ready for attachment of fixtures and other appliances. Any light in a
bathroom or damp place must be controlled by a wall switch, preferably of a double pole type.
(1991 Code § 5-118)
C. Entrance Service Switch: The entrance service switch shall be of the internally operated or safety
type and so designed as to fully enclose all connections to the meter. (1991 Code § 5-119)
D. Service Entrance Wires: All service entrance wires shall be carried in approved conduit with
approved weatherproof service head and the conduit shall be brought into the service switch
cabinet with conduit fitting of any kind except coupling or other closed fitting. (1991 Code § 5-120)
E. Breaking Of Seal: In order to accomplish the full safety features of the equipment, it shall be
unlawful for any person other than an authorized employee of the electric service company or the
electrical inspector to break any seal of any electric meter, transformer or cabinet. In case of
emergency, an authorized employee of a licensed electrical contractor may break the seal to
replace a fuse. In all such cases, the electrical service company must be notified by the party
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 265/382
breaking the seal within twenty four (24) hours in order that the box may be resealed. (1991 Code
§ 5-121)
F. Main Service Fuses: The main service fuse must be in place when the electrical inspector makes
final inspection. All installations must have branch or customer's fuses installed on the load side of
the meter, which shall be accessible for renewal without opening the main service cabinet or
breaking the seal on the same. (1991 Code § 5-122)
G. Service Cutouts: All service cutouts must be placed at the nearest accessible point of entrance; the
operating handle of all service cutouts shall be a maximum of six and one-half feet (61/2') and a
minimum of four feet (4') above the finished floor or ground level. When wiring is concealed, a flush
type cabinet must be used. (1991 Code § 5-123)
H. Switches And Cutouts: For open installations and individual motors, switches or enclosed type
switch separated from outside must be used. In mercantile buildings where there is more than one
occupancy, each occupant must be provided with a cutout within such store, or the same must be
located in a readily accessible place. (1991 Code § 5-124)
I. Electric Irons In Mercantile Occupancies: In all mercantile occupancies where electric irons are
used, they must be installed with approved pilot light. Ordinary lighting circuits must be confined to
six hundred sixty (660) watts, and not more than eight (8) outlets per circuit will be allowed. (1991
Code § 5-125)
J. Lamp Cords Restricted: Lamp cords shall not be permitted in the kitchens of restaurants or like
places where grease accumulates. (1991 Code § 5-126)
K. Nonstandard Fuses: It shall be unlawful to use nonstandard fuses, and when found in service, the
same will be prima facie evidence that the owner or tenant is responsible for their use and will be
subject to a fine upon conviction. (1991 Code § 5-128)
L. Installation Of Meters: Meters will not be installed in bathrooms, toilet rooms, clothes closets, under
stairways nor in any part of the building usually kept locked. Meters shall be installed so that the
centerline of the meter is a maximum of sixty six inches (66") and a minimum of thirty inches (30")
above finished floor or ground level. Meter socket or enclosure shall be grounded with minimum #6
AWG bare copper conductor connected to a minimum five-eighths inch by eight foot (5/8" x 8')
copperclad ground rod. Grounding electrode conductor shall be protected from physical damage
by a nonmetallic rigid conduit or equal. (1991 Code § 5-129)
M. Outlets, Receptacles In Residential Uses: To prevent the overloading of fixture wiring, each family
dwelling or apartment shall include not less than two (2) convenience outlets or receptacles for
attaching appliances. (1991 Code § 5-130)
N. Rigid Conduit: Rigid conduit or metal molding shall be used under the following conditions and
places regardless of location with respect to fire limits:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 266/382
1. In all business buildings, manufacturing establishments, mills, elevators, and institutional
buildings.
2. In all churches, schools, theaters and other buildings used for public assembly.
3. For all service entrances into the service cabinet and from the service cabinet to the first
opening.
4. Such other locations as are required by the national electrical code. (1991 Code § 5-131)
O. Use Of Metal Sockets: Metal sockets shall not be used over concrete or dirt floors unless controlled
by a wall switch, in which case they must be located at least seven and one-half feet (71/2') from
the floor. (1991 Code § 5-132)
P. White, Gray Wires: Wires having white or gray in their covering shall be used only as conductors for
which grounding is required. (1991 Code § 5-133)
Q. Use Of Old Work: Old work of concealed knob and tube or open cleat work that was installed
previous to the adoption of this article, when in the judgment of the electrical inspector is in a safe
condition, may have extensions of the same kind of work made to those installations, provided
extensions are not over ten feet (10') in length, when covered by permit. (1991 Code § 5-134)

Chapter 4
GAS APPLIANCES AND PIPING1
10-4-1: BUILDING INSPECTOR; INSPECTIONS; FEES:
A. Testing Requirements: The building inspector shall be furnished by the city with proper proving
apparatus for testing all piping. When requested to do so by the gas fitter or the consumer of gas,
he shall make a test with the proper proving apparatus and by applying a minimum of twenty (20)
pounds per square inch air pressure test on all gas piping after installation. The test shall be left
until inspection is made. Any piping found to be defective shall be ordered removed and same
replaced with perfect materials, at the expense of the person who furnished the same. (1991 Code
§ 5-181; amd. 2007 Code)
B. Permit And Inspection Fees: Fees for permits and inspections under this chapter shall be as
established by ordinance. (1991 Code § 5-181)
10-4-2: TESTING GAS METERS:
When a consumer of gas has cause to and does believe his meter is fast, the company, upon notice,
shall remove the same and test it in the presence of the building inspector. If the meter is found to be
more than two percent (2%) fast, the gas company shall refund to the consumer the amount of
overcharge according to the bills rendered for a period of three (3) months back. (1991 Code § 5-182;
amd. 2007 Code)
10-4-3: GAS SHUT OFF ON DANGEROUS FIXTURES:
The building inspector shall shut off or cause to be shut off all gas connections with residence or
business houses in the city, where in his judgment the gas fitting, ranges, heaters, furnaces, gas lights
and gas appliances are dangerous. The gas shall remain shut off until such time as the required
changes are made by the property owner or the party installing same. (1991 Code § 5-183)
10-4-4: TAPPING GAS LINES; SETTING METERS:
No person other than those employed and authorized by the gas company shall tap the gas mains;
and all interference with the company's service, pipes, stops, boxes, meters, and other property is
hereby prohibited. Upon request after application has been signed by the consumer, the company
shall at its own expense tap the main and run a line to the curb and place a stop and box there. The
company shall furnish and set a meter after a suitable place therefor, approved by the inspector, has
been provided by the consumer. No connections shall be made by the company unless and until there
is on file in its office a certificate issued and signed by the building inspector to the effect that all gas
piping on the premises to be served by the connections is approved. (1991 Code § 5-184; amd. 2007
Code)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 268/382

7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.

10-6-2: REGISTRATION OF PLUMBERS; FEE:
Plumbing contractors and plumbers working or doing business in the city shall register annually with
the city clerk. Registration shall expire on the birth date of the license. A registration fee in the amount
established by ordinance shall be paid to the city at the time of registration. License fees shall be
prorated, as established by the construction industries board, to coincide with the birth date of the
license. Licenses shall be renewed upon application made more than thirty (30) days following the
date of expiration, upon payment of the renewal and an additional fee as prescribed by the

while such holder is in military service if application is made within one year following his service

10-6-3: DISPLAY OF STATE LICENSE NUMBER ON VEHICLES:
All registered contractors shall display the contractor's state license number on the driver and
passenger sides of all vehicles used in the performance of the contractor's occupation. All numbers
shall be painted or shall be permanent adhesive labels. All markings shall be a minimum of two inches
(2") in height. All displayed markings shall begin with the letters "OK", followed by the respective
numbers. All markings shall be of a contrasting color to the color of the vehicle. (1991 Code § 5-233)
10-6-4: PERMIT AND INSPECTION FEES:
The fees to be paid to the city for plumbing permits and inspections shall be as established by
ordinance. (1991 Code § 5-234)
10-6-5: WALL AND YARD HYDRANTS; BACKFLOW PREVENTION:
All wall and yard hydrants shall be protected from backflow. All accessory backflow preventers shall
be tamperproof and shall be an automatic drain type, Watts NF 8 or equal. (1991 Code § 5-235)
10-6-6: LAWN SPRINKLER SYSTEMS:
A. Permit Required; Fee: Any person or firm desiring to install a lawn sprinkler system shall first apply
and obtain a sprinkler permit. The fee for such a permit shall be established by ordinance.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 271/382
B. System Specifications: All lawn sprinkler systems shall have a backflow prevention device installed
to protect the potable water system of the city. A reduced pressure principal backflow preventer,
Watts 909 or equal, or an antisiphon vacuum breaker, Watts 288A or equal, shall be the types of
backflow preventers approved by the city. A shutoff valve shall be installed on the inlet and outlet
of a double check backflow preventer. An antisiphon vacuum breaker shall be installed a minimum
of twelve inches (12") above the highest system outlet, when used as the protection device of the
potable water system. A main control valve, manual or automatic, shall be installed ahead of the
vacuum breaker. An automatic drain valve shall be installed between the main control valve and
the vacuum breaker to prevent freezing of the piping. The drain valve shall be protected with a
backflow preventer to prevent the entrance of contaminants into the potable water system. (1991
Code § 5-236)
10-6-7: POTABLE WATER CONNECTION:
A licensed and registered plumbing contractor or journeyman shall make the connection to the potable
water system, and shall also install the backflow prevention devices. A plumbing permit shall be
obtained for the connection to the potable water system. (1991 Code § 5-237)
10-6-8: SEWER BACKUP RELIEF DEVICE:
A sewer backup relief device (as approved by the building inspector) shall be installed in all drainage
pipe cleanouts. An example will be on file in the building inspector's office. (Ord. 870, 4-6-2004)
Chapter 7
FIRE CODE AND REGULATIONS
10-7-1: ADOPTION OF CODE:
A. Code Adopted: The current edition of a certain document, one copy of which is on file in the office
of the city clerk and copies available, marked and designated as the 2015 international fire code as

the control of buildings and structures as herein provided. Each and all of the regulations,
provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of such publication are hereby referred to, adopted and
made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section.
B. Revisions: The following sections of the 2015 fire code are hereby revised:
1. Section 101.1. Insert: "city of Clinton, Oklahoma".
2. As amended by OAC 748:20-3-1 through 748:20-3-15.
(Ord. 969, 3-15-2016)
10-7-2: LIMITS FOR STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 272/382
The limits referred to in section 5601.1.1 of the international fire code adopted by this chapter in which
the storage of explosives, ammunition and blasting agents is prohibited are the boundaries of the city.
(Ord. 972, 7-5-2016)
10-7-3: STORAGE OF GASES; CYLINDER EXCHANGE PROGRAM:
A. Storage Tanks: Outside aboveground and underground storage tanks shall be prohibited within the
boundary limits of the city, except as established by the zoning ordinance for sale of gas to the
public. Retail sales of LPG/CNG shall be confined to the heavy commercial district when storage is
underground and confined to light or heavy industrial district when storage is aboveground except
under a cylinder exchange program as hereinafter set forth in subsection B of this section.
B. Cylinder Exchange Program:
1. Cylinder exchange cabinets shall be constructed of steel and be lockable so that cylinders
cannot be removed and valves cannot be tampered with when unattended. The cabinets shall
be:
a. Vented top and bottom.
b. Set on a firm, incombustible base.
c. Kept locked when not exchanging cylinders.
d. Placed at least ten feet (10') from any building opening.
e. Placed at least fifteen feet (15') from any source of ignition such as: soft drink and ice
machines, exhaust fans, air conditioners or telephones.
2. The cabinet shall have the following signs affixed to it:
a. "Propane" or "Flammable Gas" and "No Smoking".
b. License or permit number.
c. Name of class I permit holder who supplies the cylinders.
d. Twenty four (24) hour emergency telephone number.
3. The cabinet shall be located for distance and number of cylinders as per NFPA 58.
4. Protection against vehicle impact shall be provided in accordance with good engineering
practice where vehicle traffic normally is expected at the location as per NFPA 58.
5. An approved serviceable portable fire extinguisher of not less than eighteen (18) pounds dry
chemical B/C rating, and shall be readily available within a fifty foot (50') radius of the exchange
cabinet and shall be reinspected annually.
6. All empty or full cylinders shall be:
a. Stored in a cabinet in an upright position.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 273/382
b. Valve outlet plugged.
7. All full cylinders placed in the cabinet shall:
a. Have a proper consumer warning label affixed.
b. Be requalified as per NFPA 58, appendix C.
c. Be painted white or aluminum in color.
8. A warning sign shall be posted at or near any entrance doorway stating the "LP GAS
EXCHANGE CYLINDERS EMPTY OR FULL SHALL NOT BE TAKEN INDOORS FOR ANY
REASON".
9. All employees who exchange cylinders shall be properly trained and know how to check for
leaks and what emergency procedures to take if a leak is discovered. Only properly trained
employees can remove or install exchange cylinders from the cylinder exchange cabinets. This
training shall be provided by the class I permit holder who is supplying the exchange cylinders.
This documentation will be kept at the class VII location.
10. A class I permit shall be required in order to supply exchange cylinders for the cylinder
exchange permit holder. (Ord. 814, 5-4-1999)
10-7-4: CONTAINER INSTALLATIONS:
A. Storage containers shall be limited to five thousand (5,000) gallon water capacity or less.
Multicontainer installations shall be strictly prohibited.
B. Storage and dispensing facilities shall be in strict accordance with NFPA 58 as adopted by the city.
C. Storage containers shall be located a minimum distance of seventy five feet (75') from any
incombustible structure and one hundred twenty five feet (125') from any combustible structure.
Storage containers shall be located a minimum of fifty feet (50') from any property boundary line.
(1991 Code § 7-55)
10-7-5: MOUNTED VEHICLE FUEL SUPPLY CONTAINERS:
A. Motor vehicles equipped with LPG/CNG fuel supply containers shall be permitted within the
boundary limits of the city.
B. Vehicle fuel systems shall comply with section 3-6 of NFPA 58, as adopted by the city. (1991 Code
§ 7-56)
10-7-6: LPG OR BOTTLED GAS:
A. Portable Bottled Gas: Portable bottled gas shall be permitted within the boundary limits of the city
for use with outdoor gas cooking grills. Bottles shall be DOT/ASME approved, and shall be limited
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 274/382
to a maximum of thirty (30) pounds' water capacity. Bottle containers with a maximum water
capacity of two and one-half (21/2) pounds, used with completely self-contained hand torches or
similar applications, shall be permitted, as per section 5-34 of NFPA 58 as adopted by the city.
B. Trailer Mounted Containers: Trailer mounted containers shall be permitted within the boundary
limits of the city for the purpose of supplying fuel for area heating of buildings under construction,
and for the purpose of roofing application. Trailer mounted containers shall be limited to three
hundred (300) gallons' water capacity. Trailer mounted containers shall be located a minimum of
twenty five feet (25') from all structures while in use. Trailer mounted containers shall be attended
at all times during operation. All trailer mounted containers shall have the valves closed in the off
position when unattended, and all valves shall be locked to prevent tampering. (Ord. 814, 5-4-
1999)
10-7-7: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-
4-1 of this code. (1991 Code § 7-1)
Chapter 8
SIGNS
10-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
A-FRAME SIGN: A stationary outdoor sign with two (2) faces attached at one surface on each face to
form a triangle with one side parallel to the grade.
ADVERTISING SIGN: An outdoor structure, object, display, lighting device, figure, painting, drawing,
message, pictorial picture, plaque, poster, billboard, or other thing which is used to advertise, identify,
display, or attract attention to an object, person, institution, organization, business, product, service,
event or location by any means including words, letters, figures, designs, symbols, fixtures, colors,
illumination or projected images.
AVERAGE GRADE: The grade of the finished ground level at the midpoint of each exterior surface of
a sign, or a structure, in the event that the sign is attached to the structure.
AWNING, CANOPY, OR MARQUEE SIGN: A projecting sign attached to, hung from, or painted on a
canopy or covered structure which extends beyond the building line or property line.
BACK TO BACK SIGN: A structure with two (2) parallel signs with their faces oriented in opposite
directions located not more than ten feet (10') apart. A back to back sign shall constitute one off
premises sign.
BILLBOARD: Any freestanding sign or a sign that is attached to or part of a building and is an off
premises sign.
BOARD: The planning and zoning board of the city of Clinton, Oklahoma.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 275/382
BUILDING/ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR: The designated authority for enforcement of this chapter.
CITY: The city of Clinton, Custer County, Oklahoma.
COMMUNITY SERVICE SIGN: Any sign which solicits support for or advertises a nonprofit community
use or social institution. Such signs may include, but shall not be limited to, seasonal holidays, such
as Christmas or Easter, school activities, charitable programs or religious activities.
CULTURAL FACILITIES: Establishments such as museums, art galleries, public libraries, botanical
and zoological gardens and theaters of the performing arts, which, although they may charge an
admission fee, are essentially nonprofit and principally funded through public expenditures, grants and
donations.
ERECT: To construct, build, raise, assemble, replace, affix, attach, create, paint, draw or in any way
bring into being or establish.
FLOODWAY: The channel of a stream and adjacent land areas which are required to carry and
discharge the floodwaters and flood flows of any river or stream associated with the regulatory flood.
FREESTANDING SIGN: Any sign which is not attached to or on the walls, face, or exterior of a
building, except as provided in the definition of a standard roof sign.
HANGING SIGN: A sign which is suspended over a sidewalk, street, or other public right of way. An
overhanging sign may or may not be a projecting sign.
HISTORIC BUILDING/STRUCTURE: Any building/structure which is officially designated as
historically or architecturally significant by a unit of local, state or federal government.
HOME OCCUPATION SIGN: Any nonilluminated nameplate sign not exceeding one square foot in
area.
OFF PREMISES SIGN: Any sign other than an on premises sign.
OFFICIAL SIGN: Any sign erected by or at the direction of any governmental body.
ON PREMISES SIGN: Any sign which advertises only goods, services, facilities, events or attractions
available on the premises where located, or identifies the owner or occupant or directs traffic on the
premises.
OUTDOOR ADVERTISING SIGN: See definition of Advertising Sign.
POLITICAL SIGN: A temporary sign announcing or supporting political candidates or issues in
connection with any national, state, or local election.
PORTABLE SIGN: Any sign designed or constructed to be easily moved from one location to another,
including signs mounted upon or designed to be mounted on a trailer, wheeled carrier, or other
nonmotorized mobile structure.
PREMISES: Any lot or unplatted tract, or any combination of contiguous lots or unplatted tracts held
under single ownership.
PROJECTING SIGN: A sign affixed to any building, wall, roof, marquee or other structural element
which extends or projects more than twelve inches (12") from such wall, roof, marquee or other
structural element.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 276/382
PUBLIC INFORMATION SIGN: Any sign which is intended to identify community, civic, or social
events and is not any of the following signs: commercial, political, official, or real estate.
REAL ESTATE SIGN: A temporary sign: a) displayed during and in connection with construction
operations, b) pertaining to the lease or sale of a lot or building upon which placed and not exceeding
sixty four (64) square feet, and c) pertaining to the sale of an addition or a subdivision, the area of
which subdivision exceeds one acre of land for a period not to exceed two (2) years.
RESIDENTIAL NAMEPLATE SIGN: A sign permitted for the sole purpose of identifying the inhabitant
residing therein, the house name, or identifying the address of the house. The sign may contain no
advertising of any kind and may not exceed two (2) square feet in area.
ROOF SIGN: A sign attached to a roof extending more than three feet (3') above the ridgeline.
SLOPING ROOF SIGN: A sign affixed to the roof of any building, which does not project more than
twenty four inches (24") from the roof or extend more than five feet (5') above the ridgeline of the roof
to which it is attached.
TEMPORARY SIGN: A sign that is not permanently affixed to a building, structure or the ground.
TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGN: A permitted sign for the purpose of identifying parking areas and directing
the flow of traffic on private property.
WALL SIGN: A sign affixed to a wall, marquee, or other structural element of any building, which does
not project more than twenty four inches (24") from the wall, marquee or other structural element, or
extend more than five feet (5') above the wall, marquee or other structural element to which it is
attached. (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-2: ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS:
A. Enforcement: The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced and administered by the city building
inspector and the city code enforcement officer. The building inspector and the code enforcement
officer shall have the authority to order the painting, repair, or removal of a sign.
B. Violations And Penalties: Any person, firm or corporation violating or failing to comply with any of
the terms or provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction shall be fined not more than an amount established in section 1-4-1 of this code. Each
day such violation shall be continued or shall be allowed to exist, shall constitute a separate
offense.
C. Licenses: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of constructing, erecting,
repairing, altering, installing, or relocating commercial signs within the corporate limits of the city of
Clinton, Oklahoma, shall obtain a commercial sign contractor's license therefor, which license shall
be in an amount established by resolution of the city council and made available in the city clerk's
office.
D. Permits: No person, firm or corporation shall erect, construct, install or relocate any sign within the
incorporated city limits without a permit first having been obtained.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 277/382
E. Duration: When a permit is issued, it shall be valid and need not be reissued so long as the sign for
which it is issued is left in its original location and is maintained in accordance with this chapter.
F. Permit Fees: A permit fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council and made
available in the city clerk's office shall be paid on all signs requiring a permit. No permit fee shall be
required for a sign fifteen (15) square feet or less over a show window or door of a store or
business establishment, containing only the name of the proprietor and nature of the business; nor
shall a permit fee be required for ground signs, provided such signs are not over fifteen (15)
square feet in area. (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-3: VARIANCE PROCEDURE:
The Clinton board of adjustment shall have the authority to grant a variance to the height, spacing and
setback requirements of this chapter in cases where it is determined that strict compliance with the
provisions herein will inflict unusual and practical difficulties. The Clinton board of adjustment may
grant a variance only to those height, spacing and setback requirements established in this chapter.
When application for a variance is made to the Clinton board of adjustment, a public hearing on the
request shall be held. Written notice of all public hearings on variance requests shall be given to all
owners of property, or to persons rendering the property for city taxes, affected by such variances,
located within two hundred feet (200') of any property, within not less than thirty (30) days before any
such hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation, not less than thirty (30) days
before any such hearing is held.
No notices of any application for a variance shall be given, and no hearings shall be held by the
Clinton board of adjustment until a filing fee accompanying such application is paid. The filing fee
(payable in cash, certified check or cashier's check), shall be in an amount established by resolution
of the city council and made available in the city clerk's office. (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-4: CLASSIFICATION OF SIGNS:
This section concerns the categories of permanent and temporary signs governed by the provisions of
this chapter.
A. Signs requiring a permit under the provisions of this chapter are as follows:
1. Back to back signs.
2. Billboard signs.
3. Canopy signs.
4. Hanging signs.
5. Marquee signs.
6. Portable signs.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 278/382
7. Projecting signs.
8. Roof signs.
9. Sloping roof signs.
10. Wall signs.
B. Signs not requiring a permit under the provisions of this chapter are as follows:
1. A-frame signs.
2. Community service signs.
3. Home occupation signs.
4. Official signs.
5. Political signs (temporary).
6. Public information signs (temporary).
7. Residential nameplate signs.
8. Traffic control signs (on private property).
9. Real estate signs (temporary). (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-5: GENERAL SIGN REGULATIONS:
This section concerns general regulations pertaining to signs.
A. Identification Of Signs: Every outdoor advertising display sign hereafter erected, constructed, or
maintained, for which a permit is required, shall be plainly marked with the name of the person,
firm or corporation erecting and maintaining such sign.
B. Location Restriction: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to place, erect,
construct or use any signs in R-1, R-2, or R-3 zoning districts, except residential nameplates, lease
or sale signs, and temporary signs displayed during construction and in connection with
construction operations, and temporary signs pertaining to the sale of an addition or subdivision.
1. No outdoor advertising display shall be erected, constructed or maintained so as to obstruct any
fire escape, any window or door, or opening used as a means of egress.
2. No sign shall be attached to a fire escape, nor be placed in such a manner as to interfere with
any opening required for legal ventilation.
3. No sign shall be erected on or over public property in a manner which interferes with any fire
hydrant, traffic light, or streetlight, or which hampers the functions of the fire department.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 279/382
4. No person shall place or maintain a flashing light or flashing electric sign of any kind or color
within five hundred feet (500') of the centerline of any federal or state maintained street or
highway unless a permit is granted by the state highway commission for such flashing light or
flashing electric sign.
5. No sign will be permitted in those areas identified as floodway or the 100-year floodplain without
compliance with the requirements for a special development permit.
C. Fastening And Anchoring: All signs shall be securely fastened or anchored to a building wall,
structural framing, or other foundation with a sufficient number of bolts or anchors to resist stress
resulting from dead weight of the sign and wind loads.
1. Trees, rocks, bridges, fences, windmills, towers, utility poles and dilapidated buildings shall not
be used for sign supports.
D. Materials: All signs shall be constructed of durable material and securely attached to framework
and supports made of wood, metal, or other material of equivalent strength.
E. Electric Wiring: Electrically illuminated signs, or signs which are equipped in any way with electrical
devices or appliances shall conform to the provisions of the city electrical code.
F. Sign Inspections: The city building inspector shall have the right to visit any site where a sign is
being erected, or enter any building where a sign is being constructed for installation within the city
for the purpose of making any inspection necessary.
G. Public Right Of Way: Signs projecting from a building or extending over public right of way in
industrial or commercial business district(s) shall maintain a clear height of nine feet (9') above the
sidewalk grade and all such signs shall not extend more than two feet (2') of the curb line.
Freestanding signs shall maintain a ten foot (10') setback from the curb line or zero feet (0') from
the property line, whichever is greater. A maximum height of thirty five feet (35') shall be allowed at
the property line.
1. In no instance shall a sign extend into the right of way of any state maintained street or highway.
2. No pole, post or standard used to support any sign or floodlight shall be set in or upon any
sidewalk, street, or other public property.
H. Maintenance Of Area Beneath Signs: For all freestanding signs, a one hundred (100) square foot
sign area beneath the sign shall be mowed and maintained in a neat and clean condition.
I. Sign Area Calculation: In calculating the area of a sign, the perimeter of the area shall be a line
including the outer extremities of all letters, figures, characters and delineations or a line including
the outer extremities or the framework of background upon which sign is placed, whichever line
includes the larger area.
J. Freestanding Billboard Signs In Downtown Clinton: Effective with the passage hereof, freestanding
billboard signs and roof signs will no longer be allowed in the downtown area bounded by Gary
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 280/382
Boulevard (north boundary), 4th Street (east boundary), Avant (south boundary), and 13th Street
(west boundary). (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-6: SPECIFIC SIGN REGULATIONS:
A. A-Frame Signs:
1. Location: Allowed in commercial and industrial districts.
2. Size: Eight (8) square feet per sign.
3. Number: One sign per location. Two (2) signs per corner location.
4. Setback: Behind property line; minimum of six feet (6') behind curb.
B. Back To Back Signs: See requirements for billboard signs.
C. Billboard Signs:
1. Location: Allowed in commercial and industrial districts, except where otherwise restricted
herein.
2. Size: Not to exceed four hundred (400) square feet per sign face in industrial districts and in
commercial districts.
3. Height: Shall maintain a clearance from grade of nine feet (9'), except ground signs with the
base of the sign within three feet (3') of average grade. Maximum overall height of thirty five feet
(35').
4. Setback: Behind property line.
5. General Requirements: Light fixtures and catwalks may overhang the setback lines no more
than six feet (6'); however, no part of the face or its support structure shall overhang the setback
lines.
All billboards shall maintain a minimum setback distance of one hundred feet (100') from any
residentially zoned district.
6. Additional Setbacks:
a. City parks: Three hundred feet (300') from the park boundary.
b. Cultural facilities: Three hundred feet (300') from the facility boundary.
c. Historic building/structure: Three hundred feet (300') from the building/structure.
d. All billboards shall be set back a distance of not less than fifteen feet (15') from the railing of
any overpass or bridge on any road, street or highway.
7. Spacing: Billboard signs shall not be erected along major thoroughfares closer than five hundred
feet (500') apart along the same side of the street or road.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 281/382
D. Canopy Signs: Signs on freestanding canopy or detached accessory island canopy may be placed
at any location on the canopy, provided that such signs shall not project beyond the width or length
thereof.
E. Hanging Signs: All permanent signs shall be erected so as not to overhang any street or alley.
1. Location: May be hung perpendicular to, suspended from, or attached to buildings, walls, or
canopies. Signs may also be suspended under a marquee.
2. Height: Shall maintain a clear height of nine feet (9') above the sidewalk grade and shall not
extend more than two feet (2') of the curb line.
F. Marquee Signs: Marquee signs not more than four feet (4') tall, excluding any top ornament
supported directly by the marquee or awning, may extend around three (3) sides of a marquee or
awning.
G. Political Signs: Political signs shall be subject to the following restrictions:
1. Shall not exceed thirty two (32) square feet on each of a maximum two (2) sides, in residential
districts.
2. Shall not be placed on a right of way, traffic sign, dumpsters, or signal or utility pole in any
district.
3. Shall be placed only on private property after obtaining the permission of the property owner.
4. Shall not be displayed prior to thirty (30) days before the primary election and shall be removed
from all zoning districts within seventy two (72) hours after the polls close in the general election.
5. Shall not block or interfere with the view of drivers of vehicles at intersections of streets or
streets and alleys.
6. Shall be "temporary" and "freestanding" only.
H. Portable (Or Wheeled) Signs: Portable signs shall be permitted in commercial and industrial
districts subject to the following regulations:
1. Sign shall be secured to the ground at a minimum of four (4) separate points.
2. Illuminated portable signs may be white or yellow, maximum of sixty (60) watts and shall meet
all requirements of the city electrical code.
3. Sign shall be set back ten feet (10') from the curb or zero feet (0') from the property line,
whichever is the greater. Any location not meeting this setback requirement will not be allowed to
use a portable sign.
I. Projecting Signs: See requirements for hanging signs.
J. Public Information Signs:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 282/382
1. Location: Subject to approval of the city council.
2. Number: Subject to approval of the city council.
3. Size: Shall be a maximum of six (6) square feet.
4. Height: Bottom of sign not to exceed nine feet (9') above average grade.
K. Residential Nameplate Signs:
1. Purposes: To indicate the address and/or name of the occupant.
2. Size: Shall not exceed two (2) square feet per single-family and duplex structure or one-half foot
(1/2') per each multi-family unit.
3. Height: No part of the sign shall extend above eight feet (8') from average grade.
L. Roof Signs: Roof signs shall be subject to the following restrictions:
1. Shall not exceed thirty two feet (32') in total height above that portion of the roof over which they
are erected.
2. All such signs shall be constructed entirely of steel, including the upright supports and braces,
except that only the ornamental molding and battens behind the steel facing and the decorative
latticework may be of wood construction.
3. An open space of not less than three feet (3') shall be maintained below the bottom of the sign
and the roof, except for necessary vertical supports.
4. All metal parts shall be grounded as a protection against lightning.
5. No roof sign shall be allowed to extend over a sidewalk, street, or other public property.
6. Sloping roof signs shall not project horizontally beyond the perimeters of the roof. Not more than
twenty five percent (25%) of any sloping roof area shall be devoted to this type sign.
M. Traffic Control Signs (On Private Property): Traffic control signs are subject to the following
restrictions:
1. General Requirements:
a. All traffic control signs shall be of uniform design and shall conform to the overall sign
program for the entire site.
b. No traffic control sign shall contain advertising.
c. Such signs may be either freestanding or wall mounted.
d. If lighted, the light shall be indirect.
2. Size: Shall be of uniform size(s) recommended in the "Oklahoma Manual On Uniform Traffic
Control Devices For Streets And Highways".
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 283/382
3. Height: No part of such sign shall extend above seven feet (7') from average grade.
N. Wall Signs: Wall signs are attached, on premises signs and shall be governed by the following
restrictions:
1. Shall not project horizontally beyond the perimeters of the wall or extend more than five feet (5')
above the wall to which it is attached.
2. Shall not project more than twenty four inches (24") from the wall. (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-7: PROHIBITED SIGN LOCATIONS AND TYPES:
The following signs shall be prohibited in all districts:
A. Searchlights, except that they may be permitted for a period not to exceed ten (10) days for grand
openings or other special occasions.
B. Hand painted.
C. Any signs which resemble official traffic signs or signals, or which bear the words "Stop", "Go
Slow", "Caution", "Danger", "Warning", or similar words or any sign which by reason of size, color,
location, movement, or manner of illumination, may be confused with a traffic control sign, signal or
device.
D. No lighted sign shall be permitted within one hundred feet (100') of a residential district unless
lighting is shielded from view in the direction of the residential district.
E. No sign shall be erected nearer than six feet (6') to any telephone cable, power line or streetlight
standard.
F. Signs containing statements, words or pictures of an obscene, indecent or immoral nature.
G. Double decker type signs. (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-8: EXEMPTED SIGNS:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the following signs, except that no license, bond, or permit
will be required for:
A. A legal sign in existence, or for which a permit has been issued, before the effective date hereof.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 284/382
B. Holiday displays. Temporary displays, commonly associated with any national, local or religious
holiday or celebration.
C. Home occupation signs. Two (2) nonilluminated nameplates not exceeding two (2) square feet in
area which are used to identify legal home occupations.
D. Official signs. Federal, state or local government traffic, directional and informational signs and
notices issued by any court, person or officer in performance of a public duty.
E. Political signs. See subsection 10-8-6G of this chapter.
F. Public utility signs. Signs giving information about the location of underground electric transmission
lines, telegraph or telephone properties and facilities, pipelines, public sewers or water lines.
G. Real estate signs. Temporary signs advertising the sale, lease, or development of the property on
which it is located. Such signs shall not exceed sixty four (64) square feet.
H. Residential nameplate signs. Signs indicating the name and/or address of the occupants of the
residence, not to exceed two (2) square feet in area.
I. Safety, warning and directional signs. Signs warning of construction, excavation, or similar hazards,
and parking lot and other private traffic directional signs, each not to exceed the uniform sizes
recommended by the state of Oklahoma.
1. Such signs are limited to directing pedestrian and vehicular traffic within the premises on which
they are located and are not intended to advertise a product or service. (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-9: NONCONFORMING SIGNS:
Any sign which existed and/or was permitted or erected prior to the effective date hereof and which
does not conform to the intent and specifications of this chapter is a nonconforming sign. A
nonconforming sign may remain in place so long as it is kept in good repair and maintained in safe
condition. (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-10: MAINTENANCE AND REMOVAL OF SIGNS:
A. Maintenance: All signs shall be maintained in a safe, presentable or structurally sound condition at
all times, including replacement of defective parts. All pennants, banners, streamers, spinning or
similar moving devices shall be kept in presentable condition at all times. The owner of any
property on which a sign is located and those responsible for maintenance of the sign shall be
equally responsible for the condition of the sign and for the condition of the area in the immediate
vicinity of the sign and shall be required to keep this area clean, sanitary and free from noxious or
offensive substances, rubbish, and flammable waste materials.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 285/382
B. Removal Of Signs: The building official may order the removal of any sign that is not maintained in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter. If any sign is installed, erected, or constructed in
violation of the terms of this chapter, the building official shall notify, by registered mail or written
notice served personally, the owner or lessee thereof to alter such sign so as to comply with this
chapter and to secure necessary permit therefor, or to remove the sign. If such order is not
complied with within thirty (30) days, the building official shall remove the sign at the expense of
the owner or lessee thereof.
1. Abandoned Signs: All abandoned signs and their supports shall be removed within ninety (90)
days from the date of abandonment.
2. Damaged Signs: All damaged signs shall be removed within ninety (90) days from the date of
such damage except in times of natural disaster. The building official shall have the authority to
grant a onetime extension, not to exceed ninety (90) days, for abandoned, nondamaged signs,
provided such extension is requested in writing. (Ord. 918, 9-15-2009)
10-8-11: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of an
offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by fine and costs as provided for in section 1-
4-1 of this code, unless a separate and distinct penalty is otherwise specifically set forth in this
chapter. Each day's continuation of any such violation shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 918,
9-15-2009)
Chapter 9
MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS
10-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning;
MOBILE HOME OR TRAILER COACH1: A preconstructed building, house or home that has or did
have wheels for the purpose of transporting the same on highways or streets, whether it still has
wheels or sits on a foundation, and as defined by the department of housing and urban development
as now exists or as hereafter amended.
TRAILER COACH LOT: A unit of level adequately drained ground of definite size, clearly indicated by
corner markers for the placing of a trailer coach or a trailer coach and tow car.
TRAILER PARK: Any site, lot, field or tract of ground upon which two (2) or more trailer coaches are
placed, and shall include any building, structure, tent, vehicle or enclosure used or intended for use as
part of the equipment of such park. (1991 Code § 11-1; amd. Ord. 874, 11-2-2004)
10-9-2: MOBILE HOMES OUTSIDE MOBILE HOME PARKS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 286/382
Mobile homes currently parked and occupied outside a mobile home park shall not be replaced by
another mobile home unless said replacement mobile home shall be less than five (5) years old. (Ord.
876, 11-16-2004)
10-9-3: PARKING OR STORAGE OF TRAILER COACHES AND RVs:
A. Trailer Coach Or RV; Park Use: It shall be unlawful for any person to use or occupy any trailer
coach or recreational vehicle within the city except in a designated recreational vehicle park.
B. Mobile Homes; Mobile Home Park Use: It shall be unlawful for any person to park, use, or occupy
any mobile home within the city except within a designated mobile home park.
C. Storage Of Trailer Coach Or RV: A trailer coach or recreational vehicle may be stored on private
property within residential zones if parked pursuant to subsection 11-9-4A2 of this code. (Ord. 816,
5-4-1999)
10-9-4: ZONING FOR TRAILER COACHES AND TRAILER PARKS:
Trailer parks and trailer coach lots, and the parking of trailers and trailer coaches, shall be prohibited
in the fire limits. No trailer park or trailer coach lot shall be established in any block on which one or
more residence buildings are located unless the applicant for the privilege presents the written
consent of sixty five percent (65%) of the owners or occupants of such residence buildings in the
block. (1991 Code § 11-3)
ARTICLE A. TRAILER PARKS1
10-9A-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE; DISPLAY:
A. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or operate a trailer park within the
city without first securing a permit.
B. Operation; Compliance: No trailer park shall be operated within the city except as provided in this
article.
C. Permit Fee; Term: The permit for a trailer park shall be obtained from the city clerk at a fee
established by ordinance and shall be for the period until, and shall expire on, April 30 following the
date of issuance. Applications for renewal of permits may be made within thirty (30) days prior to
expiration at a fee established by ordinance for the period of one year from the date of expiration.
D. Display Of Permit: Such permit must be conspicuously displayed at all times. (1991 Code § 11-31)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 287/382
10-9A-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
A. Park Attendant Required: Any applicant for permit to operate a trailer park shall agree in his
application that a responsible attendant shall be in charge of the trailer park at all times, and such
attendant shall supervise the park and be, together with the permittee, responsible for any violation
of the provisions of this article which occurs in the operation of such trailer park.
B. Park Plan Required: With each application, a park plan indicating the information required in the
park plan shall be submitted to the city clerk for inspection and approval of the city council. The
application for permit must include the name and address of the applicant and a legal description
and complete plan of the proposed park, containing the information required by section 10-9A-3 of
this article. (1991 Code § 11-32)
10-9A-3: PARK PLAN:
A. Overall Site Requirements: The park shall be located on a well drained site suitable for the
purpose; shall have an entrance and exit well marked and easily controlled and supervised; shall
have surfaced roads not less than eighteen feet (18') wide, well drained, plainly marked, and
adequately lighted at night, easily accessible to all trailer coaches; and walkways to the various
buildings shall be surfaced and adequately lighted.
B. Lot Specifications; Trailer Coach Location: The trailer coach park shall provide lots for each trailer
coach, boundaries to be indicated by corner markers, with an area of not less than one thousand
(1,000) square feet, with a minimum width of twenty five feet (25') and a minimum length of thirty
five feet (35'). Each trailer coach shall be located:
1. At least ten feet (10') from any building.
2. At least as far from the building line as the nearest adjacent permanent building on the same lot.
3. At least three feet (3') from the property line.
C. Park Plan Information; Map: The park plan required by section 10-9A-2 of this article shall provide a
legal description and map clearly setting out the following information:
1. The extent and area to be used for park purposes.
2. Driveways at entrances and exits, roadways and walkways.
3. Location of sites for trailer coaches.
4. Location and number of proposed sanitary conveniences, including proposed toilets,
washrooms, laundries and utility rooms.
5. Method and plan of sewage disposal.
6. Method and plan of garbage removal.
7. Plan of water supply.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 288/382
8. Plan of electric lighting. (1991 Code § 11-33)
10-9A-4: PARK REQUIREMENTS AND FACILITIES:
A. Water Supply: A sufficient supply of pure healthful drinking water, approved by the health officer,
not more than two hundred feet (200') from any trailer coach shall be provided in convenient
locations. No common drinking vessel shall be provided. Waste from this supply shall be emptied
into a drain connected to the sewer system of the city. An abundant supply of hot water shall be
provided at all times for bathing, washing and laundry facilities. There shall be no drinking water in
toilet compartments. (1991 Code § 11-34)
B. Toilets:
1. The park shall provide flush toilets in conveniently located buildings not more than two hundred
feet (200') from each trailer coach. The buildings shall be well lighted at all times, ventilated with
screened openings, and constructed of moistureproof material permitting satisfactory cleaning.
The floors shall be concrete or similar material, slightly pitched to a floor drain.
2. Toilets shall be provided for each sex in ratio of one toilet for every fifteen (15) males and one
toilet for every ten (10) females.
3. In addition, every male toilet room shall have one urinal for each fifteen (15) males, but in no
case shall any male toilet room be without one urinal.
4. Toilet rooms shall contain at least one lavatory with hot and cold running water for each three (3)
toilets, but in every case not less than one lavatory with hot and cold running water in every toilet
room.
5. These accommodations shall be based on the total park capacity according to the accepted
plans, and shall be computed on the basis of a minimum of three (3) persons to each trailer
coach, with the sexes being assumed equal in number. (1991 Code § 11-35)
C. Showers And Laundry Facilities:
1. Separate bathing facilities for each sex shall be provided not more than two hundred feet (200')
from the most remote trailer coach. Each section shall contain one shower and one dressing
compartment for each ten (10) families.
2. Laundry facilities shall be provided in the ratio of one double tray for each fifteen (15) trailer
coaches.
3. The construction of showers and laundry buildings shall be the same or similar to that
designated for toilets in subsection B of this section. (1991 Code § 11-36)
D. Sewerage And Refuse Disposal:
1. Waste from showers, toilets, slopsinks and laundries shall be wasted into the public sewer
system, or, in the event it is impossible to connect with the public sewer system, such waste may
be wasted into a private sewer and disposal plant or septic tank system approved by the health
officer.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 289/382
2. All kitchen sinks, wash basins or lavatories, bath or shower tubs in any trailer coach shall empty
into an approved receptacle or disposal system, and must under no circumstances be thrown
upon the ground.
3. Toilets and water closets not connected with the sewer system shall not be used; and it shall be
further unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of such fixtures. (1991 Code § 11-37)
E. Garbage Receptacles: The park shall provide supervision and equipment sufficient to prevent
littering the ground with rubbish and debris. Flytight metal depositories with tight fitting covers shall
be conveniently located not farther than one hundred feet (100') from any trailer coach.
Depositories shall be kept in a sanitary condition at all times. Garbage and rubbish shall not be
mixed. (1991 Code § 11-38)
10-9A-5: BUILDING AND HEALTH REGULATIONS:
A. Plumbing: All plumbing installation, alteration, or repair in the park shall be done in accordance with
the provisions of the plumbing ordinances of the city.
B. Electrical: All electrical work shall be in conformity with the ordinances of the city.
C. Permanent Additions: No permanent additions of any kind whatsoever shall be built onto or
become a part of the trailer coach.
D. Notify Health Officer Of Communicable Disease: It shall be the duty of the park attendant to notify
immediately the health officer of any communicable disease in the park. (1991 Code § 11-41)
10-9A-6: COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING REGULATIONS:
In case any provision of this article conflicts with the zoning ordinance, the zoning ordinance shall
prevail and be enforced. (1991 Code § 11-43)
10-9A-7: REMOVAL OF WHEELS:
Any action toward the removal of wheels from a trailer coach, except for temporary purposes of repair,
or other action to attach the trailer to the ground by means of posts, piers, foundation or skirting, shall
subject the trailer to the requirements of the building code as well as this article. (1991 Code § 11-40)
10-9A-8: REGISTRATION OF OCCUPANTS:
A. Required Information: The trailer park shall keep a record of all guests, with the following
information:
1. Name and address of each occupant.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 290/382
2. License numbers of all units.
3. State issuing such licenses.
B. Inspection Of Registry: The park shall keep a copy of the registry available for inspection at any
time by any authorized person, and shall not destroy such registry until the expiration of one year
following date of registration. (1991 Code § 11-39)
10-9A-9: INSPECTION; REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT:
A. Inspection Authority: The building inspector shall have the authority to enter and inspect for health
and sanitation purposes any facility licensed under this article at any reasonable time. (1991 Code
§ 11-42; amd. 2007 Code)
B. Permit Revocation Or Suspension: The city council shall have the power to revoke or suspend any
permit issued hereunder for the violation of any of the provisions of this article and order the trailer
coach parking removed or the trailer park closed after notice and proper hearing. (1991 Code § 11-
42)
Chapter 10
OIL AND GAS WELLS
10-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
All technical or oil and gas industry words or phrases used herein and not specifically defined herein
shall have that meaning customarily attributable thereto by prudent operators in the oil and gas
industry.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
LEASE: Any tract of land subject to an oil, gas and mineral lease or other oil and gas development
contract, or any unit composed of several tracts and leases but operated as one lease, and any tract
of land in which the minerals are owned by an operator or someone holding under it or him, but which,
due to the fee royalty ownership, is developed and operated as a separate trust.
PERMITTEE: The person to whom is issued a permit for the drilling and operation of a well under this
chapter, and his or its administrators, executors, heirs, successors and assigns.
WELL: Shall include and mean any hole or bore to any sand, formation, strata or depth for the
purpose of producing and recovering any oil, gas, liquid hydrocarbon or any of them. (1991 Code
§ 14-1)
10-10-2: OIL AND GAS INSPECTOR:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 291/382
A. Appointment: The city shall appoint an oil and gas inspector.
B. Enforcement Duties: It shall be the duty of the oil and gas inspector to enforce the provisions of this
chapter. (1991 Code § 14-3)
10-10-3: PERMIT REQUIRED; WELL LOCATION:
A. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person acting either for himself or acting as agent,
employee, independent contractor or servant of any other person to commence to drill, to drill or to
operate, any well within the city, or to work upon or assist in any way in the persecution of
operation of any such well, without a permit for drilling and operation of such well having first been
issued by the authority of the city in accordance with the terms of this chapter. (1991 Code § 14-
51)
B. Well Location: No well shall be drilled and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any
location which is nearer than three hundred feet (300') of any residence, religious or commercial
building without the applicant having first secured the written permission of the owner thereof.
(1991 Code § 14-52)
10-10-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FILING FEE:
A. Application And Fee: Every application for a permit to drill and operate a well shall be in writing,
signed by the applicant or by some person duly authorized to sign same on his behalf. It shall be
filed with the city clerk and be accompanied with a filing fee in the amount established by
ordinance. The fee shall be in cash, money order or certified check.
B. Required Information: No applicant shall request a permit to drill and operate but a single well. A
separate application shall be required for each well, and the application shall include the full
information, including the following:
1. The date of the application.
2. Name of the applicant.
3. Address of the applicant.
4. Proposed site of the well, including:
a. Name of the fee owner.
b. Name of the lease owner.
c. Brief description of the land.
5. Type of derrick to be used.
6. The proposed depth of the well. (1991 Code § 14-53)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 292/382
10-10-5: ISSUANCE OR REFUSAL OF PERMIT:
A. Conditions Of Permit: The city, within twenty (20) days after the filing of the application for a permit
to drill and operate a well, shall determine whether or not such application complies in all respects
with the provisions of this chapter, and if it does, the city shall then fix the amount of the principal of
the bond and insurance provided for in section 10-10-7 of this chapter, and after such
determination shall issue a permit for the drilling and operation of the well so applied for. Each
permit issued under this chapter shall:
1. By reference have incorporated therein all the provisions of this chapter with the same force and
effect as if this chapter were copied verbatim in such permit.
2. Specify the well location with particularity to lot number, block number, name of addition or
subdivision, or other available correct legal description.
3. Contain and specify that the term of such permit shall be for a period of one year from the date
of the permit and as long thereafter as the permittee is engaged in drilling operations with no
cessation of such operations for more than ninety (90) days, or oil or gas is produced in
commercial quantities from the well drilled pursuant to such permit; provided, that if at any time
after discovery of oil or gas the production thereof in commercial quantities shall cease, the term
shall not terminate if the permittee commences additional reworking operations within ninety (90)
days thereafter, and if they result in the production of oil or gas, so long thereafter as oil or gas is
produced in commercial quantities from such well.
4. Contain and specify such conditions as are authorized by this chapter.
5. Specify the total depth to which the well may be drilled, not exceeding the projected depth.
6. Contain and specify that no actual operations shall be commenced until the permittee shall file
and have approved an indemnity bond in the designated principal amount as so determined by
the city and conditioned as specified in section 10-10-7 of this chapter.
B. Signatures; Compliance By Permittee: The permit, in duplicate originals, shall be signed by the city,
and prior to delivery to the permittee shall be signed by the permittee (with one original to be
retained by the city and one by the permittee); and when so signed shall constitute the permittee's
drilling and operating license and the contractual obligation of the permittee to comply with the
terms of such permit, and such bond, and this chapter.
C. License Denial; Partial Refund Of Deposit: If the permit for the well be refused, or if the applicant
notifies the city in writing that he does not elect to accept the permit as tendered and wishes to
withdraw his application, the cash deposited as provided for to be filed with the application shall be
returned to the applicant, except that there shall be retained therefrom the amount established by
ordinance as a processing fee. (1991 Code § 14-54)
10-10-6: TERMINATION OF PERMIT:
When a permit shall have been issued under this chapter, the same shall terminate and become
inoperative without any action on the part of the city unless within ninety (90) days from the date of
issuance actual drilling of the well shall have commenced. The cessation for a like period of the drilling
operations or the cessation of the production which shall have commenced shall operate to terminate
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 293/382
and cancel the permit, and the well shall be considered as abandoned for all purposes of this chapter.
It shall be unlawful to continue the operation or drilling of such well without the issuance of another
permit. (1991 Code § 14-55)
10-10-7: PERMITTEE'S INSURANCE AND BOND:
If a permit be issued by the city under the terms of this chapter for the drilling and operation of a well,
no actual drilling operations shall be commenced until the permittee shall file with the city clerk a bond
and a certificate of insurance, as follows:
A. Bond: A bond in the principal sum of such number of dollars as has been so determined by the city,
but not to be less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). Such bond shall be executed
by a reliable insurance company authorized to do business in the state, as surety, and with
applicant as principal, running to the city for the benefit of the city and all persons concerned,
conditioned that the permittee will comply with the terms and conditions of this chapter in the
drilling and operation of the well. Such bond shall become effective on or before the date the same
is filed with the city clerk and remain in force and effect for at least a period of six (6) months
subsequent to the expiration of the term of the permit issued, and in addition the bond will be
conditioned that the permittee will promptly pay off fines, penalties and other assessments
imposed upon permittee by reason of the breach of any of the terms, provisions and conditions of
this chapter, and that the permittee will promptly restore the streets and sidewalks and other public
property of the city, which may be disturbed or damaged in the operations, to their former
condition; and that the permittee will promptly clear all premises of all litter, trash, waste, and other
substances used, allowed, or occurring in the drilling or producing operations, and will, after
abandonment, grade, level and restore the property to the same surface condition, as nearly as
possible, as existed when operations for the drilling of the well were first commenced; and that the
permittee will indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all liability growing out of or
attributable to the granting of such permit. If at any time the city council shall deem any permittee's
bond to be insufficient for any reason, it may require the permittee to file a new bond.
B. Reduction In Bond Amount: If, after completion of a well, permittee has complied with all of the
provisions of this chapter such as to removing derrick, clearing premises, etc., he may apply to the
city council to have the bond reduced to a sum of not less than fifteen thousand dollars
($15,000.00) for the remainder of the time such well produces without reworking. During reworking
operations, the amount of the bond shall be increased to the original amount.
C. Liability Insurance: In addition to the bond required in subsection A of this section, the permittee
shall carry a policy or policies of standard comprehensive public liability insurance, including
contractual liability covering bodily injuries and property damage, naming the permittee and the
city, in an insurance company authorized to do business within the state. Such policy in the
aggregate shall provide for the minimum coverage established by the city council.
D. Certificate Of Insurance: Permittee shall file with the city clerk certificates of such insurance as
above stated, and shall obtain the written approval thereof by the city manager, who shall act
thereon within ten (10) days from the date of such filing. Such insurance policy shall not be
cancelled without written notice to the city clerk at least ten (10) days prior to the effective date of
such cancellation. In the event such insurance policy is cancelled, the permit granted shall
terminate, and permittee's rights to operate under such permit shall cease until permittee files
additional insurance as provided herein.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=594 294/382
E. Reduction In Insurance Amount: If, after completion of a well, the permittee has complied with all of
the provisions of this chapter, such as to removing derrick, clearing premises, etc., he may apply to
the city to have such insurance policies reduced to the amounts established by the council for the
remainder of the time such well produces without reworking. During reworking operations, the
amount of the insurance policy shall be increased to the original amount. (1991 Code § 14-56)
10-10-8: DRILLING IN STREETS AND ALLEYS:
No well shall be drilled and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location which is
within any of the streets or alleys of the city. No street or alley shall be blocked or encumbered or
closed in any drilling or production operation except by special permit by order of the city, and then
only temporarily. (1991 Code § 14-4)
10-10-9: OPERATION OF DERRICK AND RIG:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate in connection with the drilling or reworking of any
well within the city any wooden derrick or any steam powered rig; or to permit any drilling rig or derrick
to remain on the premises or drilling site for a period longer than sixty (60) days after completion or
abandonment of the well. All engines shall be equipped with adequate mufflers approved by the oil
and gas inspector. The permittee shall keep a watchman on duty on the premises at all times from the
start of the erection of a derrick, or a mast, or a gin-pole, until the well is abandoned and plugged or
completed as a producer and enclosed with a fence as required in section 10-10-21 of this chapter;
provided, however, it shall not be necessary to keep an extra watchman on duty on the premises
when other workmen of the permittee are on such premises. (1991 Code § 14-5)
10-10-10: SLUSH PITS:
Either earthen or steel slush pits shall be permitted in connection with the drilling operation. In the
event a steel pit is used, such pit and its contents shall be removed from the premises and the drilling
site within thirty (30) days after completion of the well. In the event an earthen slush pit is used, same
shall be filled and leveled within ninety (90) days after completion of the well. (1991 Code § 14-6)
10-10-11: CASING REQUIREMENTS:
A. Casing Specifications:
1. All casing, including surface protection and production strings, shall be either seamless steel or
equivalent quality oil well casing. Each production string of casing must comply with at least the
following minimum internal pressure yield strength, computed in accordance with API standards:
Depth Of String
